So far, Darling in the FranXX has been a solid addition to the anime world, adding some great storylines and some awesome art. Judging from the first half of this series, this anime does move slowly, though that in itself is not too unexpected given it's length of 24 episodes. Personally I think that this anime has many good elements, and that it is more good than bad. Keep in mind at this time only 11 episodes have been published so this is not a complete review of the series. 
STORY: 7
As I've said before the story has two big flaws. One, it moves quiteslowly for an action/mecha story. And two, the story itself is quite redundant. On point one, it is a 24 episode long series, so having a more drawn out story is not a bad thing, but sometimes there is a lack of action and interest. As for point two, when there is action, the premise of each fight is very similar. Zero Two and her love interest Hiro are a very strong coupling, and for the first couple of episodes the story is just a repetition of itself, showing off the power of Zero two and Hiro. There are some curveballs, but most are quite weak and dont really affect the story too strongly overall, they're just there to create suspense. The story is too strongly divided, there isnt much that can happen, which makes the story quite easy to predict. If they can create conflict between the protagonists, or even create a rebellion of protagonists against the higher power, that would make a stronger statement as a story.  However, the premise, the establishment of the enemy and the progression of the protagonists all make this story a "good" story as of now. Unless things start shaking up plot wise then it will only remain a "Good" story. Also, shoutout to all the sex references in the beginning episodes. I'd love to see more of those. 


ART:9

The art is amazing. Period. The combination of the pale palette and its simplistic design does well on the eyes, and the animation itself is crisp and light. Everything flows smoothly. So far over the course of the first half of this series. The art itself is arresting without being overly complex and detailed; it is eye catching without the shenanigans of über- sharp art. It treads the line of minimalism to a T, and that is very good for the anime. Characters are designed well. 


SOUND:8

Not a huge stickler when it comes to sound, but I have listened to both the OP and ED once or twice. Which is once or twice more than many other anime's that I've watched. The sound is nice, has an electric feel when it comes to song selection. As for sound in the story, its not bad either, very subtle. And for the VAs, nothing seems out of place.


CHARACTER: 7

Here is where it breaks a bit. For the first 8 episodes almost all of the characters are completely stagnant. The only change is in Zero two and Hiro. There is a very definitive lack of progress for the characters. However, moving past these few episodes, we are then thrown into a spasm of character development that is both very sudden and unexpected. This drags the story down, but it also does not follow up on the development of said characters. So overall, the characters are not bad by themselves, but there is a definite lack of development for these characters, at least for a good third of the entire series. 


ENJOYMENT: 9

Despite these flaws, I still really enjoy this anime. The combination of romance with mecha, action, and some quality art really makes me invested in the story. As of now, I can't believe that the anime has already gone for 11 episodes. It makes me sad that there have already been 11 episodes, until i remember that there are still 13 more to go. I look forward to this anime every week. Although the Characters and the story are somewhat weak, this anime still excels as a simplistic anime with some social commentary and an interesting take on the new dystopian world genre. 


OVERALL:8

Overall, this anime is pretty damn good, but its not an amazing anime. Storyline wise it brings some new elements and plot, but overall it is nothing new. The art is great and the sound is also pretty good, but the characters are a little to flat and negelected by the storyline. Overall, so far, I'd say that a 3 for art + 2 for story + 2 for characters + 1 for enjoyment = 8 overall

Mecha anime has unfortunately become less popular over the years. Not many anime studios these days don't seem interested or have the budget to make a mecha anime. If they do, they normally incorporate different genres in their mecha anime. They hardly ever get talked about these days. That is until this particular mecha anime series comes out and becomes one of the most talked about anime of 2018. An anime made by two familiar names in the anime industry, Tirgger and A-1 Pictures to mabye spark interest in mecha anime once again. But the question is, was this show actually good? 
Well i'm aboutto tell you. Sit back, Relax, put on your pink wig and say "Yu...." I mean "Darling" as I present to you the anime review for Darling in the Franxx. Lets begin. 




Story 5/10


The story takes place in a post-apocalyptic future where humanity has resided into mobile plantations since the world is left barren and overrun by mysterious beings known as Klaxosaurs. In order to protect the plantations, APE, the government in charge of taking care of humanity, uses teenagers known as parasites to pilot mecha known as Franxx. One pilot, Hiro, cannot somehow pilot a Franxx until he meets a mysterious girl who is half human and half Klaxosaur by the name of Zero Two. From there, Hiro vows to know more about Zero Two and starts to see the world he knows from a different angle. 


Now obviously this is not the entire plot as more of the plot is uncovered as time moves on and we know more about the world. Speaking of which, lets start by talking about the show's world building. The shows world building is cleverly done as it slowly builds as more of this world and its residents is revealed through the eyes of our characters. Our cast of characters don't know much about the world as we do. We learn as they learn about the world and what it was like before they lived in plantations and outside The Garden, a facility where the children grow up and train to become Franxx pilots. It's cleverly used with a lot of subtle hints placed across the show, giving us an idea about the world and how society views these teenagers. That is until until we get a massive world building explanation dump near the end of the show where it tells us the backstory of the world and reduces interesting plot developments into uninteresting and generic plot reasons that pretty much kills the mystery of the show fast. It feels like the creators didn't no how to tie up all of this world building, so they must of thought that a text dump would suffice. That is just being lazy. 


It is also a double edge sword. By doing this type of world building, this show starts really slow. It does have a rocky start that struggles to get itself any traction of moving the plot forward. Without a good hook, you will struggle to keep watching this show. With how generic Hiro's character is (and we will get to that) it can be quite a slog. Over time though, the plot does get more interesting as more is explained to us and the characters personalities gets more fleshed out...during the middle part of the show where the plot really shines. However, the show struggles to keep that momentum during the final act of the show where it uses recycled plot points that is overall just lazily done with a plot twist that really feels out of place and doesn't work with the context of the show. It more or less tries to get to a conclusion, rather than building for a second season. With the plot twist that was in the show, it could've worked. It rushes to tie up all plot points so things get little to no context behind them, leaving us with questions which the anime doesn't provide. 




Characters 7.5/10


Lets start on a pretty low point with the characters section and talk about our main protagonist, Hiro. Hiro is just a standard, generic protagonist. He just doesn't have anything that makes him stand out and that is a problem when he is the main protagonist. You normally want your main protagonist to stand out among the cast but he doesn't do that. What makes him generic is that he is nice to his friends, he broods a lot and doesn't really get what other people are thinking as he is just unaware to it. He does what other countless protagonists do and there just isn't anything that makes him unique. That is until we get into the middle of the show where he actually starts to become more interesting as more of his backstory is revealed and we understand why he is the way he is. So thankfully, he does get better but that doesn't deserve immediate praise when he starts out generic and then goes back to being generic by the end of the show. 


Then we get to Zero Two. Zero Two is best girl. You may argue with me but deep down you know i'm right. She has a very lively personality that she uses to cover her more darker side that makes her character the most interesting of the show. Early on we see her character being shrouded in mystery as we know little about her when she is introduced. All we get from her is that she is a very lively character that does what she wants and she doesn't want anyone to stop her. Over time though, her personality starts to change as things are getting more and more curious by the second and we see that she isn't always an upbeat and lively person as her Klaxosaur side gets to show its face more often. Zero Two is indeed the character that has the most interesting qualities as we want to know more about her and why she is like the way she is. She also has the best smug face. 


Next, I want to talk about Ichigo, the leader of the parasite squad, Squad 13 since she has points that are worth talking about. Ichigo has a very interesting personality which, unfortunately, stirred up some controversy surrounding episode 14. She is very much a character who has her feelings and emotions cloud her judgements half of the time since she has had a big crush on Hiro ever since they were children. This also gets her emotions to dictate her decisions for better or for worse. She is a very polarising character because on one hand, she is very much a character who cares for Hiro and the rest of Squad 13 and that makes her a caring person. On the other hand though, it does mean that she can be unbearable sometimes as her emotions and feelings can get the better of her and clouds her judgement. This is what makes her a good character though as she is only doing what she thinks is best for Hiro and Squad 13 because she is a caring but selfish person. 


I could go on talking about every main character on this show but I'm not going to otherwise we will be here for a while. But all of Squad 13 have personality traits that makes them unique and recognisable. It makes their interactions with one another intriguing because each character have their own traits that make them fun to watch and care for when things go south. It kind of makes sense when they are surrounded by side characters with similar or the same personalities. These characters stand out because they need to. They need to be recognisable in order to stand out. That doesn't mean the characters are stereotyped. They aren't. Each of our main cast is fleshed out in some way that makes them easily stand out in the main cast overall and makes their conversations more grounded in reality as they learn and understand new things when they have no idea what they are. 




Animation 8.5/10


Now what happens when you combine the art style and over the top action of Studio Tirgger and the polish and beauty of A1 pictures? A really good looking anime. It is like if A1 pictures took Trigger's art style and sanded off all of the sharp edges to make it look smoother. It still has that studio Trigger style with fast paced, awesome visuals that we know Trigger can do but with a more polished feel to look even better. This is especially true with the environments as they can look gorgeous sometimes. 


The character designs as well leave subtle hints about the world they live in and that is clever, being part of the overall world building. That being said, Hiro looks generic but everything else looks good. This is especially true with Zero Two's character design as she really does look like a half human and half Klaxosaur with her red horns and inhuman eyes but still manages to look human. 


The design of the Franxx goes for a more slicker mecha design feel with some mystery behind them. They don't look chunky like most mechs, instead they go for a more slimmer approach which honestly make them look good. They animate well and are recognisable because of their designs were intentionally meant for them to stand out. But when Streliza comes into play, things start looking awesome. 


However the animation does take a dip in the fight scenes in the final act of the show as A-1 pictures took over that aspect from Trigger and considering how good the fight scenes during the beginning and middle of the show, that's disappointing.  



Sound 9/10


The soundtrack is one of the things that Darling in the Franxx gets right. Whether it is used for the mecha scenes or when it's used between conflict between the characters. There is always a soundtrack to match the situation when it is required and definitely adds to the atmosphere. One track that stands out to me is when there is conflict between the characters and a ominous music plays in the background where it feels like there is some tension building and it is not looking good. This one would stand out as my favourite..... if it weren't for the show's opening song. 


Speaking of the openings, they are both amazing. From its visuals, its sybolysm, and of course, the song "Kiss of Death" by Mika Nakashima x Hyde blends it all together to make them incredible openings. It also takes the Guran Lagann route of the second opening merely updating the visuals and including the second half of the song to make it more appropriate for the second half of the show. While both really good, the second one is my favourite for having better visuals. Fun fact, if you translate it, it is about Zero Two telling her Darling to say "I'm here, please don't be scared and run away from me." 


The endings as well are also generally good and are good to listen to. But the one that stuck to me was the one that was only shown in one episode, episode 13. It shows the plot device used in the episode and acts like it is foreshadowing something that is going to happen in the future. 


I have slightly positive feelings about the English dub. On one hand, I applaud all the voice actors and actresses on doing a good job with the dub to make it enjoyable and a good alternative to the Japanese dub (it is done by funimation after all). On the other hand, i'm not a big fan of Matt Shipman being cast as Hiro. Even though it is just one complaint, being the main character means we have to listen to him quite a bit. He just sounds older than he looks and sounds a bit too "negative" all of the time.  



Conclusion


Darling in the Franxx is either a show you are going to love or you are going to hate. There is no in-between. While it has a great cast of characters, very good animation and a great OST. It does have a slow start and it does lose quality during the latter half of the show as well as having a generic protagonist in the form of Hiro. For a show to be truly great, it has to nail its quality from start to finish. Darling in the Franxx struggles with maintaining its quality, only really peaking during the middle of this show. It does have things going for it sure, but it also has quite a bit of problems as well. But one thing is for sure though, it is nice to see a mecha anime get this much attention as it has. Mecha as a genre, needed to get this kind of attention in order to show that there are still plenty of people who love mecha anime. 


Darling in the Franxx is anime I recommend you watch if you are looking of a good mecha anime to watch. I don't think it lived up to the hype this show was getting but on its own, it's still an enjoyable anime to watch. But I won't fully recommend it since the story is a complete mess. 


My Personal enjoyment: 7.5/10



Overall score: 7.5/10   Recommendation: Consider it

This isn’t your typical action and robots show.
As someone who is a huge fan of mech shows like Gundam and Macross, I was a tad skeptical to watch this show.  The show began with a group of inexperienced pilot kids with girly-looking robots and a ton of sexual references so my first impression of the show was not that great.  I had heard good things about the show so I decided to push through and continue watching.  The first 5-6 episodes of the show did not “wow” me, but my feelings towards it changed shortly after.
It was at this point that theshow started peaking my interest.  The characters that I thought were young and immature began to experience lessons about life, came face-to-face with death, and started developing into something much more tolerable.  In fact, I began to really like the characters, especially the main two – Hiro and Zero Two.  Love begins to blossom in the show and more character backstories are revealed, which are unique and make you really feel for the characters.\n
As the story continues, there are other things taking place behind the scenes.  There is this whole mystery of why the kids were born/made, what the higher powers are really up to, and who exactly Zero Two is.  The kids begin asking themselves things like “Why was I born?”, “What is my purpose in life?”, etc.  I didn’t think a show like this would even touch upon deep life questions such as these and it really makes me appreciate the show in general.\n\n
What started off as an unappealing sexualized mech show turned into a show about love, learning from your mistakes, and dealing with fear and unknowns in life.

TL;DR: Solid, realistic and complex characters and relationships. Fun fights. If you can emotionally invest, you may like this. 
DARLING in the FRANXX is the new coming of Neon Genesis Evangelion paired with Tengen Toppa Gurren Lagann and hints of Kill La Kill. In this wonderful mix of styles we get to experience a marvelous story that takes us into the chaotic and emotional mess that is childhood & puberty.
It gets its mecha and teenage drama from Evangelion, the style and cartoonishness from Gurren Lagann, and the Ecchi seems mostly to like that of Kill La Kill.
Contrary to popular belief, this show is not aboutsurviving in a post-apocalyptic world fighting giant monsters with mechas, oh no no. Rather, it's a metaphor for the emotional turmoil our main characters are going through. They're thrusted into a cold and callous world in which they're abused and restricted and they have to deal with it.\n\n
If you can get emotionally invested in characters then this might be a show for you. You will experience sadness and hope and many other emotions. The show accomplishes this remarkably well and, in addition to this, is able to hold my attention. It's well-paced and the characters are relatable and likable. There's no real edginess or pretentiousness to the characters.\n\n
I'll update this once the show is done.

As many other reviews here have pointed out, if the basic plot premise of Darling in the Franxx doesn't interest you, you're not going to get anything else from the show at this point. Ignoring the few and far between shows that manage to bridge the genre gap between niches, if you are actively against mecha and shounen tropes, this show is not worth your time. 
However, if you have even considered watching this show, annoying fan-service non-withstanding, I highly suggest you give it a go, at least until episode 13. Similar to how episode 5 was the climax of the first arc of theshow, episode 13 capitalizes on the previous episodes of character development and hints at the start of a resolution, while making the viewer ask more questions in the process.  


All of these previous episodes were building up to this climax in episode 13, so, if you're over the first hump and unsure whether or not to go forward, I implore you -- don't talk down to half a story.

The art and soundtrack are quite good, but insufficient to salvage this mess of tired tropes. Darling in the Franxx sets out with the goals of character development and worldbuilding, and succeeds at neither.
All of the characters are one-dimensional stereotypes: our generic protagonist-kun, his unlucky childhood friend, his magical tsundere girlfriend who is in love with him just because he isn't afraid of her horns, the big guy who loves to eat, the studious girl who wears glasses, the childish rival... Nonetheless, entire episodes are devoted to characters making the discovery that they are in love with their piloting partner, who they have obviously compatiblepersonalities with. The only interesting character is Zero Two, the half-human love interest with a quirky yet dark personality, and she is out of focus.


But what Darling in the Franxx suffers most from is painfully slow pacing. I enjoy stories that take their time when done well, but Darling in the Franxx has no direction— it feels no closer to a conclusion halfway through than it does in the beginning. At the end of an episode, it never feels like anything has been accomplished. Whenever something interesting happens, it is cast aside: the tiny glimpses of worldbuilding lead to no further exploration; a character develops a mysterious disease seemingly as a result of piloting with a certain partner, only to be suddenly fine and dandy in the beach episode with no comment. 


There is also the blatant aping of Neon Genesis Evangelion. There's a SEELE-like governing council of mysterious masked men, an arrogant, talented female pilot in a red suit, video displays with orange text and caution lines, a mech entering "stampede mode" revealing sharp teeth... homage is fine but without the despair and horror this is all without reason and, frankly, insulting.

 I've seen a lot of 1s recently here, mostly from people missing what DiTF is about, and so I'm here to help you understand this show better, and if not like it, maybe appreciate it a little better.
 The following is a rant I'm taking from another post in another website, so I'm sorry if it's not as well written as it should, but it does it's job in conveying what I have to say about this show.
DiTF isn't about Hiro, nor mechas, nor romance, nor about space battles. All of these are simply tools used tomake a story and talk about the themes in it. It's a show about a dystopian society coming to ruins and the rebuild of the world and humanity.\n
Something I've seen a lot is parallels of Magma Energy and Oil - to say this parallel is central is the equivalent to say that Harry being british is a central theme of Harry Potter.\n
DiTF starts innocently as a lewd show with mecha fights and sex innuendos, but it cleverly uses this superficial appearance to hide it's intentions and sneak them for latter, and them twists the innuendos to make the whole icing on this cake. The real problem here is that they made such a good job at it in the beginning that by the time they wanted to talk about the central themes 90% of the audience wasn't ready for them because they couldn't expect this coming from this type of show.\n
If this is a failure of the audience or the author, I don't know.\n
 The show is full of symbolism. The first is Magma Energy. Yes, it has a few parallels with oil and such. But that's not what Magma Energy is meant to symbolize. Magma Energy is the soma of DiTF, it's a miraculous objects that sits at the core of their society. It's the ignition to the changes in their world. Therefore, Magma Energy can not and should not be explained scientifically - it's purpose is simply to exist as something we can connect to real life. If it is explained to the point of turning into tangible object in the viewers mind, all parallels stop making sense. Yes, this is a "it's magic" explanation. Much like the One Ring is meant to be a symbol for evil, Tolkien never cared to explain how it did the things it could, because it was never necessary.\n
 Now, talking about the VIRM. The VIRM represents many things. At first, they are the World Government, much in the likes of Brave New World. A central power that completely controls society, with a monopoly of means and information. That much is obvious, but their philosophy is rather interesting.\n
The VIRM believe in abandoning the physical body and entering a state of pure happiness in the collective of minds in another plane. This is the Garden of Epicurus. No, not the something from the show, but from the (non) greek philosopher Epicurus. A man who believe that through isolation and meditation people could, and should, leave this world from their minds and get a glimpse of this inter-plane state where the gods lived, where there is nothing physical and existence is pretty much nothing and matters of the terrain are meaningless. This is very important to understand the entire show.\n
 The VIRM not only created a machine that exactly reproduces this Garden of Epicurus (as seen by the old-woman's husband), but they pretty much send Hiro to this Garden during the final fight. A place of nothing, disconnected from this world entirely. \n
And how is Hiro brought back? Through faith and connections.\n
Here we can see how Hiro's arc makes a brilliant follow up to the whole plot of the show.\n
He starts as one of only ones who fight against the VIRM, and then meets with a superior being, 02. Here 02, although she looks like a demon, takes the symbol of an angel. Both suffer, and both are tainted by the VIRM. As they develop together, Hiro regains his memories, 02 is brought back to her angelic position, and eventually Hiro transcends his humanity in what is pretty much a Origin Mythos becoming a saint to the people left on Earth. All of these transitions happen naturally up to the last minute, where you can finally grasp what their author's intentions were.\n
 This is why the 02 statue is so important. It makes absolutely no sense in logical terms, BUT it makes absolute sense in the symbols and themes of the show. Hiro - "Hero", if you didn't catch it already - and 02 spawn a semi-religion within the people in Earth, and sacrifice themselves for them. They even perform several miracles throughout the whole series, and specially in their last moments.\n
It's this newborn faith in the humans at Earth that saves Hiro. It's this faith, that goes against everything Epircurus preached, that breaks his Garden and brings Hiro back for his final moment.\n
Of course, this has nothing to do with religion, as faith and spiritually do differ from religion, and even any buddhist parallels are thin here, but that's not here not there. What is important is that from now on all we will see is about the struggle to defeat the VIRM and reconstruct the world, and the authors considered spirituality and faith as two fundamental pieces of this .\n
 So, if Hiro transcended humanity and became a saint, who died for humanity's sins and postponed the VIRM war, then what about the Klaxosaurs?\n
They are a failed race. Not in the sense that they are inferior, but that they were far superior and were ultimately defeated by the VIRM. Meanwhile, the humans are far weaker, and surrender to the VIRM, only to be saved by Hiro and their own struggle. \n
This is how we can understand the character arc of the most important character of the show, Dr. Werner Franxx.\n
Werner starts as a important scientist who pushes his field further by means that are considered imoral. This isn't a cautionary tale against science, however, but against lack of understanding, as Werner will learn.\n
There is a lot of clever dialogue in his episode that explains his intentions, but to delving into that requires a rant as big as this one to explain it all, so I will focus on the ideas here.\n
 Werner loves humanity, and his goal was to make better humans by removing their weakness. A metaphysical weakness, mind you - he didn't want to make us stronger or faster. The APE brings him under their wing and together they create immortal humans at the expense of our reproduction. In Werner words, this strips us of any beauty. And he was right, the post immortality humans are shallow, lonely, living in the emptiness of a semi-Garden of Epirucus where they await their final call, simply existing for the sake of it, without being able to leave lasting imprints, without being able to fight or change or grow.\n
This realization leads to his disappointment in humanity, that culminates with the death of his last hope, his wife, as he further and further falls in love with an ancient race of better humans: the klaxosaurs.\n
 Only after Werner turns into a mad man obsessed with klaxosaurs is that he turns from a somewhat questionable scientist to a truly evil man. His arc ends with him giving up on the klaxosaurs by giving a new chance for humans to fight.\n
That sets the other important matter for the reconstruction of the world. Family. Werner's greatest crime, which led to the end of human beauty, was destroying the family unity. Immortal people who couldn't connect to others and couldn't procreate couldn't make families.\n
And so, on the other hand, we have Kokoro and Mitsuru, who's connection was so strong, thanks to their daughter, that it transcended their "death" - if we are our consciousness, and that is made of our collection of memories, erasing years of memories is effectively killing a that person.\n
This is also shown in other aspects of the series, such as Nana's motherly instincts and feelings.\n
 With this, we can already tell the downfall of humanity in DiTF: people willingly surrendered to APE and their promise of paradise in the Garden, which ended up with the destruction of families and, latter, of human beings themselves. Locked in the metastasis of contemplation, they simply awaited, for nothing, unable to change. It took angels and humans from outside of that Garden to take the fight to the VIRM.\n
This culminates in the battle of VIRM against Klaxosaurs, where humans are left out for most of it, confused to what is happening, all of them having to choose between falling into the Garden or taking up arms. The sense of confusion in the viewer is partially out of a pacing problem, but also deliberately caused to put us in the shoes of the characters. Again, if that was a good decision is hard to say, but it servers it's purpose well.\n
 Finally, as they fight of the VIRM and Hiro and 02 reach the final stage of their arc towards ascension, back on Earth we see humans struggle to rebuild what was lost.\n
It's important to notice here that their main motto is not to develop on top of the Garden, but to go far back to their roots and learn from the humans of before. This could not be more Japanese, although it still is an universal theme. They reject the new and try to at least imitate the old ways, some that they don't fully understanding, but that bring meaning and beauty to their lives. This is very well presented by Kokoro's and Mitsuru's marriage. The kids don't fully understand marriage, but they can see it's good and fulfilling. And thus, the final nail in the reconstruction comes: the traditions. \n
Humans lost their traditions, but the kids brought them back, as much as they could, and even set up new ones for the future generations.\n
 To conclude this, DiTF is truly not about Hiro, 02, romance or nothing of the sort. It's central theme is far deeper: it's about the destruction of human society from the inside, by loosing sight of the things that are beautiful and give us meanings, replacing them with a desire of not suffering. It's about understanding that suffering is another part of life and it cannot be separated from us. It's about understanding the importance of beauty, family, traditions and faith - and no, this isn't political at it's core. \n
If you can't understand this, you surely can't enjoy DiTF's presentation. After all, if you take the theme out of a work, it's pretty much just meaningless colors on the screen (or mindless symbols on a paper). I don't hope to change anyone's opinion nor taste, but I do hope to make some of you at least to appreciate it a little bit more and maybe get something of this show.

After just having finished the series, coming to MAL seeing some negative reviews i was wondering if i really not getting what everyone else was. Seeing everyone else very insistent that this anime is the worst thing to ever come out the entire year and it deserves 1/10s across the board, i was really afraid that 2 entire decades of media consumption really left me tasteless and soft. Full disclaimer: This is my very first MAL review and i am normally never on this website, i visit it once every blue moon just to see what people thought of some stuff i end up caringabout. If you think that reason is good enough to discredit my review feel free to do so, i wouldn't hold it against you. And this review will be spoilers free, all i will mention will be vague words like "ep 19 twist" or "ep 20 twist" which no one should be able to know about without watching them.


Firstly i just wanna start by mentioning how i was weirded out at first, i was seeing 1/10 reviews pop up left and right with everyone agreeing with them, i was seeing people be overly harsh and at first i thought i was going insane, that i legit lost my taste and my ability to discern good media. But after reading some of the reviews, i think i see the problem. You see, everyone seems to be under the impression that DitF is a mecha shounen anime made by trigger to recapture the glory of TTGL, but, well this isn't definitive, but myself and most people i talked about this with can't view DitF as anything BUT a romantic drama DISGUISED as a mecha shounen anime. It's a show where the entire world and everything are mostly allegories used for how we all were as teens, discovering love and lust we felt for the first time, how the unstable hormones made us feel and act like and how we ended up discovering a lot about ourselves and everything revolving us. Course that's not to imply the entire show is an allegory when some things are definitely done for the world itself and not as a meaning for something else altogether, it's still definitely a mecha shounen at various places, but at it's core, i don't think this show is anything but a teen romance drama. And that's why almost every choice made in it, even if it may seem illogical or unreasonable at first, links back to that. It's trigger using the medium of mecha shounen as a way to tell us the romantic drama of teens going through their lives. 


Now as i said this is not 100% true, and it definitely focuses on it's mecha parts and builds it's world for itself and not as an allegory numerous times and at some of them, well, for me an especially notable moment where it failed to do so was episode 20. I was really, weirded out by episode 20, i still think it means nothing at all and they just wanted to make a weird twist, and i think when i look at episodes like ep 20 i can certainly understand the disappointments of some people. However i do not think the entire series deserves a 1/10 just because of a bad twist in a single episode. The point is arguably subjective depending on how much you feel like that twist ruined the series but i don't think it did, i just think it should've been better handled. At it's core i enjoyed franxx because i never viewed it as TTGL reborn, i viewed it as a teenage romantic drama about characters discovering their feels and themselves. As such i don't consider it the best mecha anime out there, i still think it's a good mecha anime because i did like the world it ended up creating even tho aliens dood was really not necessary, but the worldbuilding and lore was pretty well done outside that tadbit in my opinion.


Summary;

Story - 6: A fair story that tripped itself with ep 20 but still managed to have a good lore and world 

Art - 8: I don't know how to word this without being subjective, i'm not an artist, i just really enjoyed the art and unique, star driver esque mechas

Sound - 8: Again, not much to go on without being subjective, good sound design and a good soundtrack

Characters - 9: As i explained in the review i wrote, when you view DitF as a romantic teen drama, and you understand why they tend to do illogical or emotionally driven actions, you tend to realize they are deeper than they appear to be and a lot of them reminds me of me and my friends in my teenage years, going through discovering ourselves too.

Enjoyment - 7: Gonna say 7 here because if you view DitF as a mecha shounen, TTGL is just better at enjoyability.

Overall - 8: And maybe i really am going insane here, maybe years of media consumption really left me soft and non critical, where i accept anything i find small personal reasons to attach myself to. For that reason i'd understand if you disagreed with that review, but please do try to keep an open mind instead of viewing this review as the ramblings of a fanboy.

If I had to say anything about Darling in the Franxx, it would be to not trust the negative reviews on this one. When I first found this, I scanned the reviews and saw nothing but negativity. A little wary, I decided to watch it anyway. This turned out to be the best decision I could have made, and this show now holds my first review and my first 10/10.
Darling in the Franxx is a heartwrenching story about young mecha pilots fighting giant biological creatures from deeper within the earth's layers. Those who are now in charge of the earth have chosen children to pilotspecialized machines in order to fight these creatures, known as Klaxosaurs. At the beginning of the story, we are introduced to a young boy called Hiro. He has sought isolation after failing the tests required to become a pilot, and retreated to a private location to sulk. It is here where his life is changed. He meets Zero Two.


Zero Two comes in with a bang. Though from a distance it may look like her character is shallow and chiche'd, there is no presumption more false. 002 and Hiro develop a bond unlike any other either of them has experienced, and change the face of the Franxx program. As the viewer watches, 002 becomes more than just an edgy, self-obsessed teen and becomes a character deserving of love, attention, and respect. Her transformation was one of the most incredible developments I've seen thus far.


This goes as well for the rest of the main characters in squad 13. Though most of the reviews I've seen say differently, I felt a real connection to the characters and I grew greatly attached to them as the show and storyline progressed. As I watched their struggles and triumphs, I grew with them and bonded with the hidden depth in each of them individually. This was a show where at the end, it was truly heartbreaking to have to say goodbye. 


As for storyline, it was fantastic. There are no spoilers in this review so I can only say that there is a big plot point at some point in the series that blew my mind right out of the thermosphere. It enthralled me completely. While it does take a while to get there, the storyline preceding that point is still very well written. You still develop connections to characters, you still comprehend plot points, and it's intriguing enough to leave you always wanting more. There are plenty of animes I've seen with storyline much less compelling than this one. At the end of the show, I was left with more emotions than I could handle, and to me that proves the writing is worthy of great praise.


There's not much for me to say about the art style. It's gorgeous animation and art, the characters and creatures are detailed and fun to look at, and the world is interesting and thought-provoking. All-around amazing.


Overall, Darling in the Franxx really baffled me. I am in love with everything about it, and it has definitely left a lasting impression on me. If you're reading this and questioning if you should watch just like I was, this is your sign. I highly recommend this for anyone and everyone.

I should have written this review when the anime stopped airing, but I felt compelled to write this now. 
And of course, if you haven't watched it yet....
SPOILERS!!!!
I'm just going to summarize the good parts here. Darling In The FranXX started off strong. The first half leading up to the mid-season finale was great. I loved it. This was turning out to be 9/10 material and I was excited for the last half of the season. 002's Character was great as well as her bond and chemistry with Hiro, and him trying to be a better pilot and find the right partner. The symbolism ofintimacy and love in this show was, at times, a little over-the-top and sometimes rather sweet and lovely. The worldbuilding was top-notch, hinting at things without giving it all away in exposition dumps. There was the rest of the cast to explore as well as this interesting world. The art is fantastic, the sound is fun as hell and the world this story is set it is very interesting and fascinating. The story in the first half started off kinda slow but it got really good. It even explored some really dark stuff.


THEN THE LAST HALF HAPPENED.


When the last half of the season hit, it took a nosedive. The rest of the cast got explored to some extent, but they mostly got awkwardly shoved into romantic triangles or things were taken to uncomfortable levels; two of the characters trying to have a kid for example, when they themselves are still kids and not even young adults. In a way, I understand trying to show how these kids "deal" with these emotions since they've been locked up and not been allowed to explore themselves like human beings, but this could have been handled MUCH better. The marriage part was also weird, and it was made even weirder with the baby being added to it since again, THESE ARE KIDS. 


The plot twist that the Klaxasaurs (I hope I spelled that right) were originally fighting aliens who wanted to basically make everyone a part of them felt rushed and felt like bad writing. A good twist is one people can guess and see coming, but not to a point where it's incredibly obvious. That's part of a good mystery. This was a twist used for sake of NO ONE COULD LITERALLY HAVE GUESSED IT. Then the Franxx went into space, and it was never shown in any shape or form they could handle going into space, and 002 turned into a giant, space mech which was not explained and completely random. The show went full WTF at this part. I was so angry and upset by this that I couldn't bring myself to watch the last episode, and watched a summary of it instead, and it was exactly as I thought it was. I actually liked the twist of the Klaxasaurs having a queen, and saw a contrast between her and 002 and would have LOVED to see them have a Showdown, but that, of course, it didn't really happen, at least to the extent that I wanted. 


Darling in the Franxx was 2018's biggest disappointment for me. I really liked this anime in the first half and was so excited about it. Now I never want to watch it again, and thinking about it only breaks my heart because it had so much potential, but it's like Studio Trigger and A1 Pictures couldn't get their shit together in the last half, and it caused this anime to bomb HARD. The rating for this anime went down A LOT as the last half aired, going around 400 to 500 on MAL, above an 8, to being above 1000 and now at 7.5. THAT'S A BIG DIFFERENCE and the last half of the show is the reason why. 


I wish I could enjoy this anime as much as I did in the first half. I would have happily bought the Limited Edition Bluray that got released if the last half was of the same quality as the first, but it wasn't. and I can't bring myself to watch it now because it just breaks my heart to something so good get wasted. The anime does open itself for a second season, and if one DOES get released, I will be VERY cautious. But if they do, I hope they fix the many mistakes they pulled in the last half. 


So as of this, I give the aspects of this anime these ratings.


Story: 3 

Art: 8

Sound: 9

Characters: 4

Enjoyment: 3

Overall: 4


All of these low scores would have been higher, but the last half lowered them that much. In the first half, the lowest score you'd have seen would be a 6 for the characters, but everything else would be higher.

I don't write many reviews because most of the time I agree with most of the reviews already written for the shows I watch. Darling in the FranXX is a bit different, though. For this show I see incredibly mixed reviews. It seems that either people love it or they hate it. I disagree with these views. I really like the show, but I know it isn't perfect. If you are planning on watching the show, here is what I'll say:
The "plot"(so far) has alot to do with teenage drama and relationships between characters, which is done surprisingly well most of the time. I'd giveit a 6.


The music is pretty damn good. However, the soundtracks are meant almost solely for the show and aren't great on their own like many other shows. I'd give the music an 8.


The art is great. However, I was expecting the art to be better considering it's trigger's big comeback. I would put the art somewhere below One Punch Man and above Overlord II. I'd give it a 9.


Now for the characters... This is probably the hardest thing to rate because the characters in this show don't have much backstory to them. That said, the lack of backstory makes many of them surprisingly interesting and mysterious. 02 alone is probably one the most interesting and mysterious characters that I've ever seen in an anime. This show isn't amazing, but for some reason I am more excited to watch this show than any show I can remember for the last 5 years or so. If I was to pick a category that has caused this the most, I'd have to pick characters. I'll give them a 10.


Personal Enjoyment: 9


Overall Quality: 8

Darling in the Franxx plays in a post-apocalyptic world were giant beasts are threating humanity. Luckely that all the plot we need to put all those attractive females into lewd situations.
Darling in the Franxx is widely considered one of the most influential anime from the current season, if not of all time. It is extremely well known for its brave attempts to turn the mecha genre on its head, its deep character development, and its unorthodox storyline. Created by acclaimed studio Trigger, and written by the praised (and sometimes hated) Kim Kardashian, Darling in the Franxx has been called a masterpiece by anime fans. Doesit deserve this praise.


Simply, yes.

I find this anime very difficult to rate in the same way I rate other anime, because of its Structural issues, and problems which ruined what it had going for it. 
First I would like to discuss the first 15 episodes. These episodes had an amazing quality to not only animation, characterization but also story in general. The show heavily borrowed from other Mecha shows such as Evangelion, and Gurren Lagann, but in these episodes it managed to show them in a newer way. However many people can dislike the show for its "lack of originality" I enjoyed its unique take on the themes toother similar shows. Through a balance these episodes achieved an effect on me that I had not felt for a while since I started watching anime, So I give this aspect of the show 9-10. This is because it created unique characters and a great setting and feel in these episodes


However, just because the first 15 episodes where handled in my *opinion* almost perfectly, it cannot excuse the lackluster, and awful quality of the remnants left over namely episodes 16-24. These episodes display an extreme lack of quality and direction. I believe that after 15 they had Absolutely No Idea where the story had left to go, and instead focused on the battles which was not the primary thing that interested many in the story. Diverting their attention from more pressing drama they instead decided to add a backstory episode ruining the immersive feel of discovering the world with the cast, only to add more fights and end with a lackluster space battle. All of this DESTROYED the tone, character development, and story in my opinion. ALL of these episodes are below a five. There are so many different ways they could have ended it, maybe one that actually aligned more with the themes showed in the first episode, but instead they had to ruin everything. 


Its possible the ending could have worked if they had more episodes to flush out the story, and fix problems that could have been fixed with more planning. It feels as though they only planned up to episode 15 and then just went 'well... what now.' the characters are together and happy for a moment how do we end this off?' and someone replied 'PUT IT IN SPACE AND TURN EVERYONE INTO A FLAT CHARACTER, F*** YEAH!' and they actually listened and did it.


To fully show my opinion on the show I will average my thoughts of the episodes individually to show how I rated the series.


I rate the first 15 episodes with a 9.5/10 making 142.5

the 16th episode is a 4

17 and 18 are 3

19 is a 1

20-24 is 2

Averaging 142.5 +4+6+1+ 10=163.5/24 = 6.8125 which when rounded is a 7 so that is my overall rating. Instead of completing the themes it brilliantly layed out in the first minute of the first episode with its imagery and symbolism it ruined everything it built with a poor fitting ending and destroying anything positive


I suggest that if you are going to watch this show watch the first 15 episodes, and no more. Also the manga is looking pretty good so far, but it could turn into a crapshoot as well. Hope they decide to make it good.

What every review won't admit: this show is average. 
Gonna keep this to the point. It seems most people compare this to Evangelion or Gurren Lagann, but I couldn't help feeling I was watching an Eureka Seven alternative. I throughly enjoyed Eureka Seven (while not typically enjoying mecha animes), so that was my bias after the first few episodes.
Story: 2
This was is no way interesting, let's get this straight. The premise had potential, but in the end this show offers as generic an ex machina plot as you'll ever find. Predictable, weak character development, terrible world building, inconsistent pacing, incoherent & vague themes & ideas,and some moments make you question "what were the last 3 episodes for?" But hey, I wasn't here for the plot.


Characters: 5

The characters were great. As unoriginal as they were, I loved them. They played out their tropes like they should've. Evil guy was evil, looks evil but not really evil, good turned bad, good guy main character and friends. But again, not here for their personalities. 


They were all nice to look at & were as consistent as you'd expect from a shounen. I didn't find the "filler cast" to be abysmal either. They (for the most part) did enough to warrant their screen time. In the end, they were nice to look at, and that's all that matters-- especially our seasonal waifu(s).


Art + Sound: 9

Excellent. Animation MUST be good for this type of anime, and it was. Nothing groundbreaking, but it felt clean, looked great, consistency seemed surprisingly solid throughout, and world detail never seemed to be lacking. Fight scenes always felt up to par-- and that's a huge plus for a shounen.


Enjoyment: 5

This is really the thicc of it. If you're looking for any shred of decent plot, you won't find it here. If you're looking for aesthetics, your fill of shounen fights, and a waifu or 2- maybe even 3, this might be worth a watch. This isn't amazing, but neither a waste of time. If you're looking for the best, THIS ISN'T IT. If you're scavenging through seasonals and in need of some hyped up bullshit, go for it.


Overall: 5

I binged this in 2 days and never got bored of it, so that's something. I also don't want any more of it, so that's another thing. I got my share of shounen action & waifu time out of here, so I'd say it was worth my time of that purpose. Would I recommend this? Nah, but if you're interested don't let the MAL reviews deceive you, its neither a 1 or 10. There are much more disappointing animes with a similar score.

Man oh man. This series has been a wild ride. Personally, Darling In The Franxx has been one wild ride since I started this show back in April and let me tell you, this show is absolutely amazing.
Let's start with the basics.
Characters - 10: The characters in this show are absolutely done well and the development of them gradually get's better and better. At first glance, they seem like cliches such as the tsundere (Miku) or the childhood friend (Ichigo), but once you get to know them better you'll start to see that each character is perfectly written and each one of them has theirown detailed backstory. The best part about these characters. especially the supporting cast, aren't just there just for the sake of being there, they are part of the story and not just some cliched annoying side characters.


Story - 9: While the story was amazingly told, I have to give it one major con, it get's rushed (especially during Episodes 20 and 23) although it wasn't AS rushed as many people say. Nevertheless, the story is fantastic and ins't generic like most mecha anime's. Also. another draw back is that some of the earlier episodes contain A LOT of fan service, which I found was annoying and dumb to include, although it disappears after a few episodes. Alot of people where VERY unhappy with the ending but myself personally, found the ending to be a beautiful closure to everything we have experienced. 


Art - 8: The art in this show isn't on the level of Makato Shinkai level of animation but it was good nonetheless. The battles are amazingly well done, especially when the FRANXX take out the Klaxosaurus' by impaling them although there are times where the animation get's a little silly and there are times where it get's lazy but it was a sight to see nonetheless


Final Thoughts: Darling In The Franxx has many ups and downs, happy and sad moments, moments that made our jaws drop, and moments that moved us, but in the end, this anime has to be one of my all time favorite mecha series and I would consider it one of my all time faves. Darling In The Franxx, with a combination of an exciting plot, great characters and fantastic art, makes this show one hell of a ride.

In this passage, I’m not writing about the individual staffs behind this show, nor attributing its flaws to them. I’m trying to give a comprehensive review of this show, or explaining why it fails, plus some of my personal issues with it. It’s long but I feel necessary. Also, it is subject to my expectations*1 and personal feelings.
The most severe problems definitely lie in the plot. From my perspective, this show is just selling TOO MUCH. I’ve got mecha action, drama, à la Gainax plot, lots of characters and tons of nuanced implications, and, in horror and despair, watched them blend into an atrocious pileof trainwreck, which is executed in an equally schizophrenic manner with below-average art for a mecha anime.


Below I will try my best to analyze them.


First let’s discuss about the worldbuilding. When I first saw the PV, I was deeply intrigued: barren world, struggling people and unknown menaces, just like any other classic shows of its kind. I kept quite a bit passion to the premise alone—until I started to observe inconsistencies in earlier episodes. But that was just the beginning. As the show progressed, my passion was overwhelmed by questions originated from plot holes and unexplained items. But I maintained a sense of curiosity: How will they explain it? The final episode slammed the cruel answer on my face: they won’t. If any of them does get explanation, you'd expect it done without articulation. Those ignored plot devices have a profound impact on the show’s quality. The same speculation can be applied to those hard-handed nomenclatures. A ten-minute googling cannot add much depth to a barren show. It becomes even more disastrous in the last few episodes when gaudy things popped up one by one. When they are unable to conclude the story, the production team just kept cramming those fancy stuffs to the end, preventing us from using our brain.


Pacing is another major flaw. the production team prefers to conclude every plot arc within one episode. Critical episodes are very rushed and underdeveloped, while some others are complete waste of time. This problem with pacing is exacerbated due to crude plot arrangement, we have one third of all episodes dedicated to side characters and drama. There’s simply insufficient space for any in-depth character and plot development.


The flaw above can be traced back to a more fundamental issue: theme. Apart from ripping off elements from its predecessors, the production team desperately incorporate commercially successful tropes that seems to be from a starter’s book, but they are obviously unable to determine what matters for them. As the show progresses, I have to adjust my own expectation. Finally at the last few episodes, I gave in.


Another storytelling issue is that they heavily rely on recyclable tropes, they literally use Deux ex Machina to resolve plot conflicts and eliminate the nuisance to make quality fights.


Since the show is more character-driven, I will talk about those characters in a more specific way.


The protagonists: the male protagonist is more of an archetypical Japanese male protagonist. On the contrary, The female protagonist starts with very distinct physical and personal traits that earns her overwhelming compliments and even a personality cult*2. During the first course, the interaction and development between these two are enjoyable and endearing, yet heavily foreshadowed. Its one of the more likable part of the show, but things start to change in later episodes. The two protagonists towards an unfavorable end: they become overtly obsessed with each other.  Hiro became a jerk who cares more about his girlfriend than anyone else, even those who grew up with him. Zero Two lost her original attractiveness and plummeted into a love-driven yandere as shown in ep14, one episode after the zenith. Promises and love manifestations became ubiquitous. Their behavior in the second course disregards, and blatantly exploits, their former selves, wrecking their characters beyond salvation.


The deuteragonists: I picked them out from rest of the squad not because they are the most controversial, but how they became such. They receive considerably more characterization than their peers at an early stage, as well as a more complicated story. From my perspective, these two are supposed to be inspired by the protagonists and go through their unique growth. Sounds like Kamina and Simon, right? The problem is, instead of being integrated, their story arc severely interrupts with that of the protagonists and the main plot. Furthermore, they don’t do a good job distinguishing themselves from the rest of the team, giving false expectations to audiences and later infuriates them.


Rest of the "main" characters: They are two-dimensional from start to end. They have identical backgrounds and ended up homogeneous. They got their own character arcs, which takes a significant portion of the show, but did make some of them likeable. After that, they just degrade to puppets of their labels. The only characterization they’re ever entitled is shouting the exact same lines in different ways. And they don’t serve any purpose for late-show central plot. That leads me to a sad verdict: they are redundant. After all, no one can sufficiently portray so many characters even in a half year show along with other stuffs. Maybe animations like The Idolm@ster (I did not watch) can manage to do it, but sci-fi is another realm.


The rest are essentially plot devices, some of whom are themselves plotholes.


The final major problem with this show is the animation. The art style is distinct, using minimal shades to emphasize the lines and a rather muted tone which suits the show well. We’ve got characters by the same person behind Anohana and Your Name, which is an eclectic choice. To be fair, there are decent mecha action shots here and there. However, as a mecha show carried out by some of the best team we can expect, it’s a huge disappointment. Those quirks I mentioned above was overshadowed by mediocre battles, filled with out-of-place CGs, cheap special effects and recycled shots. Facial and body errors are rampant, even in those long, static shots. Some episodes look like products of layers of outsourcing. It would have been more acceptable if that were the case.


If we turn our focus to something other than the show itself, we may find some efforts that the show lacks. The production companies are really ambitious. They made 4-coma comics that summarize each episode and caricature famous artworks and movies. They cooperated with Kadokawa to publish their official manga, which seems essentially R-18 doujinshis right from Comiket, except thicker. Trigger also organized online Q&As on Reddit and 4Chan. Comparing the answers from the producers and what I really got just disappoints me even more.


Some more personal issues:


1: Before this show airs, I immersed myself in finished, more classic Japanese animations, of which quite a few were made by Studio Gainax and its later incarnations, namely, Trigger. Gainax impressed me with its elaborate, psychological characterization, wild deconstruction and interpretation of Sci-Fi animes from 70s and 80s, experimental narrative, story, and execution, as well as opulent animation, which most contemporary animations lack. As a matter of fact, I still reserve EVA, for a more mature and knowledgeable self. So, when I first knew the show in September, 2017, I was hyped, and maintained a high expectation that is unrealistic in hindsight.


2: Personality cult—I found it accurate to described what happened to the subreddit r/darlinginthefranxx. It started with some lovely fan arts of the female protagonist and related exclamations. But during the later episodes, these contents started to overwhelm the whole subreddit and became ubiquitous, alienating anyone else who would like to make some memes or have civil discussions about the plot. Similar incident, though less prolonged, happened again, when people outraged towards another main character, and started some sort of witch hunt. Theoretically, adhering to a group will inevitably polarize one’s opinion and weakens individuality. In this regard, this subreddit is an excellent evidence.


It’s the very first show I invested to watch simulcast, even its original airing on Tokyo MX despite language barrier, as well as the only one I followed through the last half year. Now I’m not really sure if it’s the last.

I'm gonna be honest, I bought into the hype of this show early on. I tried hard to defend it, but after several episodes, it became pretty apparent that Darling in the Franxx was a load of crap. Being a collaboration between two big studios, Trigger and A-1 Pictures, it is obvious that Darling in the Franxx would generate a lot of hype throughout the anime community. While it did start off with some potential, the end product certainly missed the mark.
Story - 3/10
It's gonna be pretty difficult to talk about the "plot" of this show without mentioning some spoilers, so be warned. 
Wow, theyreally shit the bed with this one. The story in Darling in the Franxx is just plain awful. Everything is told at an extremely slow pace, and ultimately ends up being unoriginal and not worth the time. Have you seen Evangelion? Gurren Lagann? Eureka Seven? Elfen Lied? Gunbuster? Shinsekai Yori? Well then, absolutely nothing in this show will surprise you in the slightest! The core problem with this show is its lack of identity. It tries to tackle many different themes and make references to many other popular shows, but does so with poor execution. This show has absolutely no balls and none of the plot lines go anywhere. Everything is just severely underdeveloped.


One of the main themes of this show is sex. The pilots are all underage and have to control the Franxx robots together in a doggy style position. Given how much fanservice is in the show and the absurdity of its metaphors, it is almost impossible to take anything seriously. I do give credit to the show for attempting to tackle these issues, but the execution was really clumsy. Many of the episodes try to comment on puberty and marriage, but end up being really cringy to watch. Franxx tries to take itself seriously, but none of the commentary bears any meaning. It seems like more of an excuse for underage fanservice.


I have already mentioned the world building, but let me elaborate more since it was one of my greatest disappointments with this show. Take episode 10 for example. Zorome gets lost and is taken in by a couple for most of the episode. Both the man and woman are adults, but the husband is kept frozen in storage. Is this every mentioned again? Nope! This is the most boring dystopia I have seen in recent memory. Darling in the Franxx does not develop on any of these details. It prefers to pull out beach episodes and talk about sex instead of creating an interesting world. In retrospect, it seems like the studio had no real plan for this show, and just made stuff up along the way. This is evident by how stretched thin the plot is and all of the boring twists that occurred in the last few episodes. Everything stopped making sense by that point.


Another key aspect of Franxx was the romance. It was obvious from the beginning that Hiro and Zero Two were going to get together. What leads up to it is a bunch of teen drama and inconsistencies between the characters. Only in an Elfen Lied-esque flashback episode do Hiro and Zero Two finally accept each other and become a lovey dovey couple for the rest of the series. Honestly, even Elfen Lied had more emotion behind this lazy plot device than Darling in the Franxx. If I'm saying that Elfen Lied did something better, then that should REALLY put into perspective how half-ass Darling in the Franxx is. Honestly, resolving the romance half-way through only made the show even more boring. After episode 15, I had lost all interest in the show and knew that nothing could save it. 


The ending was the final nail in the coffin. I was nearly on the floor laughing at how much of a joke the ending was, if you can even call it an ending! All of the ex-Parasites work together to rebuild society while Hiro and Zero Two go off to fight VIRM with no definite answer on whether they will actually win? At the very least show the could have had a satisfying final battle, yet the studio denied fans even that. Usually I don't think an ending can break a whole show, but stringing viewers along for several months only to give such a disappointing ending is a huge punch in the face. There are still plenty of plot holes left open. Who is going to govern society? What's the deal with the adults? Are they all sterile? If so, are all of the parasite, in their short lifespan, expected to bear enough children to continue the human race? Are they all going to be manufactured in test tubes? What about the rest of the world? Did VIRM control this city, or the whole planet? Are the Klaxosaurs just gone now? I could go on and on. Sitting through this show for 24 episodes gave absolutely no satisfaction. 


While there is plenty more to discuss, I feel like most of it has already been said in one form or another. The story of Darling in the Franxx was really bad, and probably the worst aspect of the series. 


Characters - 3/10


The cast of Darling in the Franxx is extremely boring and uninspired. By the end, I did not give a shit about any of them in the slightest. Let me give a brief rundown on each character.


Hiro is the main character. A complete joke of a main character I might add. In the first few episodes he had some sort of internal conflict going on. He was not getting along with the rest of the squad. Very quickly this got phased out and he became duller than wonder bread. Hiro is more like Kirito from SAO. A Gary Stu with no real flaws. He really lacks development in this show and words cannot emphasize how boring his personality is.


Zero Two is the only reason why people watched this show. Honestly, she was certainly an entertaining character in the first half of the show. She had a fiery personality and was the center of attention in every scene that she was in. Once the romance is resolved however, she became a boring moe and does almost nothing for the rest of the show. Her character development is a joke. She does a complete 180 when she finds out Hiro was her real "dahling" and suddenly gets along with the whole cast!


Everyone hates Ichigo, but honestly, she was ok by the end of the series. It was frustrating to see her gang up on Zero Two in the beginning. She didn't end up being a good character either, but I at least felt indifferent about her by the end.


Goro seemed like a cool character but basically got no attention in the second half of the series. Basically a background character for the most part.


Kokoro wants to have babies with Mitsuru, whose character was really confusing. Mitsuru had this burning hatred for Hiro at the start of the series but this sort of fizzled out. Mitsuru cuts his hair to signify his change of character and decides to make babies with Kokoro instead of bullying Hiro.


Zorome and Miku were basically background characters too. Zorome did have an episode of his own and he also bullied Hiro in the beginning. Even with this attention early on, he came off as really uninteresting, sometimes even annoying


Ikuno was a lesbian I think?


Futoshi's entire character is being fat. He likes food and Kokoro. Gets forced to run the wedding between Mitsuru and Kokoro. How embarrassing.


Naomi was Hiro's original partner. She was in the first episode and came back in the last episode. Ok.


Dr.Franxx appears early in the series, gets an episode to flesh out his backstory, and then dies. Cool.


None of the characters are interesting enough to mention. I give this category more points than the plot since they try to develop some of the characters. There were a couple that I liked and I couple I didn't like. Nothing offensively bad, just really underwhelming.


Art - 7/10


The animation in Franxx is usually pretty good. While there are some shortcuts made, everything about the show looks pretty nice and smooth. The scenery is very lush and colorful, everything stands out well in this show. Each of the parasite kids wear the same outfits, but they are still easy to tell apart by their hair and facial features. Zero Two, while not necessarily original in her design being a cross between Lum and Lucy, certainly looks appealing and stands out among the cast. After all, her design is the sole reason why people probably watched the show in the first place. Franxx designs look like McDonald's toys, but I found the Klaxosaur designs to be interesting at the very least. The few action scenes in the show, primarily occurring in the earlier episodes, are well animated and fluid. The action scenes toward the end were anticlimactic, but didn't look bad at all. Visual direction is solid in the show. Future events are definitely foreshadowed earlier in the show using the visuals. I should also mention that both of the openings for the show are well animated, but honestly nothing mind blowing.


While the art of this show deserves praise, it is not without its shortcomings. I have already touched upon the usual shortcuts made in the visual production and the stale designs. The greatest issue I have with the animation is the missed potential when it comes to the mecha battles. After the first few episodes, the mecha battles are kept to the sideline and are barely even highlighted in the middle of the show. While I thought the mechs themselves looked silly, the show would have been more worthwhile if there were more action sequences to compensate for the stale narrative. Instead, the show switches between a lot of the same locations which boring really quickly. Darling in the Franxx is honestly a good looking show, but was still lacking in this department. 


Sound - 6/10


When it comes to sound, Darling in the Franxx wasn't bad, but certainly underwhelming. Most of the battle music is pretty average, with no tracks that really stand out. I thought the OP "Kiss of Death" was fairly good, and it fit with the narrative of the show, but it still wasn't a piece that really stood out to me. The second OP was just a remix of the first, so I don't have much else to say other it being a lazy move. I really liked the first ED "Torikago" and thought it was really catchy. I especially liked the way that they ended each of the episodes off with it. However, the show really disappointed me by only using it for the first six episodes, and switched to mediocre tracks for the rest of the series.


The voice acting was alright throughout the show. Most of the voices fit the characters and their "personalities". Although most of the performances felt kind of boring, I did think that Haruka Tomatsu did a fine performance as Zero Two. Simply uttering the word "dahling" causes millions of adolescent males around the world to squeal. As for the English dub, I thought it was ok. If that's what you prefer, then by all means go for it.


Enjoyment - 4/10


The first six or so episodes of Franxx were fairly enjoyable, but it only started to go downhill from there. Franxx's lack of identity made for a conflicted viewing experience. Did it want to be a cool mech show? A teen drama? Nonsense? Probably the latter is most appropriate. The filler and fanservice were cringe worthy. The plot went absolutely nowhere and I had to force myself to finish the last few episodes. 


Overall - 4/10


I admit that I bought into the hype of Darling in the Franxx, but I was completely delusional. I do not recommend watching this show. If you really like Zero Two then litter your room with figurines or watch some highlights online. Alternatively, if Darling in the Franxx does interest you, or you finished the show and actually did enjoy it, then I would suggest looking at the recommendations below. Almost all of the shows there are probably better than Darling in the Franxx. My personal recommendations are Eureka Seven, Evangelion, and Gurren Lagann.

Darling in the FranXX is a collaboration between Trigger Studios and A-1 Pictures, it's a sci fi mecha, with inspiration of Neon Genesis Evangelion and Gurren Laggan. 
One thing before reading anything else, most of the work in production is done by A-1 Pictures, Trigger has only helped in some fighting sequences and as of episode 23, Trigger hasn't put a hand in production since episode 15.
Story (05/10)
The writting is a mess. Most of the first episodes were done almost perfectly but after episode 6 it began to stray it's way. Giving each 'main character' an episode, which is done wrong because after those fewepisode focusing on the 'main characters' they return the way to Zero Two and Hiro (or two real MCs). To tell you straight, in the official page and official info delivered tell you that all of Squad 13 are the main characters but since the start of the series, everyone except for Hiro and Zero Two, were just there to stop the story from advancing. Then in episode 13 we get a flashback episode explaining half of the origins of Zero Two, which rose again the quality of the series, but after episode 14 strayed again it's way, showing that the creators didn't knew the reason for the story, and as for episode 23, they still don't know.

The art is cool, but not original or fresh.

Enjoyment (06/10)

You can really enjoy the first few episodes, but after that is just nonsense after nonsense.

This anime is completely outstanding. Let me get the visuals and sound out of the way: The character design as well as general artwork is absolutely beautiful. Later in the series when they change intros, the new intro artwork is absolutely gorgeous with neon colours. The music is also topnotch. The story is wonderful as well. Just when you think its going to end good or horribly, the next part comes and everything is resolved with such determined little kids. The character development is very sad. Having caught up on this series in less than 12 hours, I can tell you this is probably one of those empty shell types that people have just hyped up somehow. 
What bothers me the most is how "mysterious" the creators try to make the plot and the characters but fails to emphasize the dystopian nature of the whole anime (which I really didn't get a solid feel of until past the halfway mark). Although there is some character development, it isn't necessarily relevant to the whole plot in general and was usually cast aside when the anime shifted focus (way too often and failed to establish a main focus until the end of the series). \n
