This is my first review on this website, so as such I am going to type up a worth while review.  Be aware that I have little to no experience with these studios as I usually just watch an anime on occasion when the whim strikes me.  So, this is a review without bias for or against the studios.
First and foremost on my mind about this series is this:
The way the mechs are piloted.  I am a scientist and engineer, so watching this technical choice really annoyed me.  Fan service should not replace good technical choices, but should compliment good technicalchoices if the fan service is needed at all.


Secondly:

I have read disappointment in the character development, but the character development is rather accurate psychologically.  People need time to change and will actively fight change, especially if they think they are right and don't want to change their long cemented way of thinking.  Emotions and relationships are often messy, so incorporating militaristic group tactics with the minds of emotional pubescent children struggling to understand these emotions with zero psychological oversight is rather interesting.  This show seemed to be about the dynamics of human nature emerging through indoctrination, with a main love interest being the center piece.  I really like Kirito in this anime (I couldn't help myself).  The main character is probably the least realistic character and needs more depth.  At episode 18 there is development, but it took a little long to get there.


Lastly:

There is a building twist coming, which is the second main focus of the anime; world building.  I am hoping to see something truly thought provoking, but I think I know how things will go.  If you read enough old books and recognize certain cliche's, it is hard to be surprised.


Overall I liked this show.  I was watching it to see different 3D animation styles because I am starting to animate with my brother for future VR endeavors and I was not disappointed.  I will continue to watch the show and see how it fairs over the last 6 episodes.  I would recommend this show, but would like to liken the progression to Violet Evergarden, meaning the Emotional aspects are the absolute main focus and the secondary feature is the world around them.  It's good on many levels, but could have been amazing had the studios took more time to really blend emotion and world building aspects.

Darling in the FranXX is an anime that disgusted me: the most despicable and insulting anime I have seen. I would watch a full season of Pupa over this if it even exists.
Story: 2
The story has a plot which basically revolves around the relationship between the heroine Zero Two and the hero of the story, simply named Hiro, and anything outside of their relationship is basically trying to separate the two, including but not limited to everything. Somewhere along the line, they and the other people of their team get into those robots which are called "Franxx", which are piloted with amale and female, controlled by getting into what is basically the "doggy style" position. And sometime else, the heroine and protagonist's relationship wavers, but moments later they're back together stronger. The genre listed "Mecha", but for those Franxx becoming stronger purely because of "love" is complete nonsense. Zero Two and Hiro have demonstrated this power in the anime, but why did they not share this with the rest of their team? It doesn't make sense to not give out the way to get this gain of power and therefore have stronger support. If I would predict something to happen, it would probably be that out of nowhere, the rest of the cohort would have a similar upgrade to their Franxx and defeat some threat in episode 24. If anything, the plot does not even relate to sci-fi or mecha; the plot can easily be in a high school anime, and would still make far more sense than in a mecha setting. Furthermore, while this story is set in a dystopian future, the technology that is presented in this anime is baffling. The gate bypass shown with Zero Two and Hiro might be a "bug" in the security, and that's acceptable. However there is no reason technology couldn't have a robot that could be piloted by a single person, and even if they can't, why would they engineer it so that people could feel pain through the Franxx? Why do they have to pilot in a doggy style? Honestly they should have the "Ecchi" genre because piloting the Franxx is really just a metaphor for sex. Or a metaphor for their relationship. I don't know, and frankly it doesn't work in the field of logic. 


Art: 4

Honestly, if the show were to get any award out of luck, it would be for art. But even then, if the art awards was simply based on the best outlines, Darling in the FranXX would potentially be a contestant. What I mean by this is that the outlining is good but the colouring feels as if the artists just used the paint bucket tool all over it and tinted the colours to fit the scene. Alright maybe that was an exaggeration seeing that I believe most anime are like that, but the art in this anime seemed to feel... bland. Furthermore, the colouring of the main cast's Franxx in comparison to the other teams' Franxx is questionable: If the teams were meant to fight with each other in Franxx, why do the main cast's Franxx have the colour palette of power-ranger suits? (Probably for merchandise or to let the audience know that there are main characters inside them). Well, the action scenes have some commendable merit, but I've watched all of Naruto and most of Naruto Shippuden a long time ago, and I can say that their action is better than Darling in the FranXX by a very large margin. Also the art seems to vary quite a lot. I've seen massive, detailed explosions, the vast, bleak but well-created environment, and the detailed flowers on the table close to the window in the anime, however I remember more flat colours in the anime than I could recall detailed patterns. I believe that the story and art don't correlate. The budget is in action, but the writing is in drama. I would like to make a small nitpick though, at the first episode Zero Two was bleeding red blood from her head. What's important was that later, Zero Two was shown to be bleeding BLUE blood. Which colour is it???


Sound: 3

Huh? Sound?

All the sounds that I could hear in one episode are the intro, cool sound effects, people talking, and that soft background music turned down to 25% in adobe after effects. I'm not saying that I watch the anime with my eyes closed and my ears wide open, but I'm saying that the sound does not make more of an impact than it should. If there's a fight scene going down, that "music" is either toned down just because the anime producers are too afraid that the music will drown out the voices and sound effects. Or when Hiro fights again after discovering a diamond in the rough, that epic music is also toned down. I don't remember the music as much as say Boku no Hero Academia's OST, JoJo's Bizarre Adventure's OST, or even Monster Girl Quest OST. It's just my opinion, but it's not my fault that I don't feel hyped, sad, or anything more when sound exists in this anime as it is. That one memorable part of a soundtrack that really makes you powerful, like probably in Attack on Titan or The Avengers? It sticks into your head and makes you want to cheer for the good side. Darling in the FranXX? I didn't hear that.


Character: 1

As the story revolves around the relationship between the protagonist and heroine, Shrek does it better. The main character is a fumbled mess, he gets depresso, the heroine gives the protagonist a figurative espresso (or maybe a little "something" better than espresso), and then somehow he defeats the monsters with the same robot he failed to defeat them with, only with more power than all of the gods combined in Norse Mythology. See, I've vaguely repeated this part in the story section, however the part I want to focus on is how Hiro is an obnoxious dude who despite literally everyone else telling him not to pilot with Zero Two, Hiro nonchalantly says "Nope, gonna do it". Zero Two is in the same boat, pushing everyone away and doing everything, even harming others to just be with Hiro. But when Hiro sees the suffering Zero Two caused to his friends, he runs away in fear, making Zero Two all sulky for sympathy points from the audience. And then they get back together. There is initially no reason why they should bond with each other, and then later it was revealed that there is a reason, but it has been forgotten. Okay I concede that how they executed this idea didn't impact the story much, however what grounds does Hiro have with Zero Two that makes him attracted to her in the first episode? The only sane person with the guts to stand against her is a comrade to Hiro, named Ichigo, who despite her backstory as a childhood friend and wants to be with Hiro, is nonetheless a passing thought in Hiro's mind, just another love interest, just another background character, just someone else, and later just another "cockblocker", as named by the audience. Ichigo was trying to pull Hiro out from the danger, but due to the anime god being so merciful on bland self-insert protagonists, Hiro only thinks that piloting with Zero Two is the only way he's be of any use. The score for character is only a one just because of Ichigo, I wanted to rate this lower. All the other characters are basically cliches, I believe the other characters were Naruto, Fatso, Iida-kun, guy from Koe no Katachi, and I forgot the rest. There are literally three memorable characters in the anime, and two of them are assholes.


Enjoyment: 2

As I stated in the beginning, I usually watch anime before bedtime, but boy... I don't feel so good.

The clock will strike midnight, but before it does, seven hours earlier I pass out due to a sleep-inducing drug called "Darling in the FranXX"

A story is divided into: narrative, plot and concept. It is normal to confuse a poor execution of plot and a bad narrative, consequently, with a poor concept, nevertheless there can be a great concept with a very bad execution; but this is not the case with Darling in the FRANXX.
DiTF has a bad, absurd, concept; but this is not the major problem. It is possible to have an absurd concept and have a great source of entertainment, after all, the absurd is interesting to watch; as long as the absurdity is not sold as something that should be taken seriously, and that is theproblem here. Darling in the FRANXX sells a concept of world-building that spits in your face while wearing a purplish galaxy clown costume and still wants to be taken seriously.


Darling in the FRANXX is far from entertaining, much less a serious show.


We have a whole construction of the world that refers to a -vague- criticism of society, with emphasis on the vague, because it is no more than that; tries to reach something, a message underneath the cloths but only for the sake of S I M B O L Y S M.


But you did not get the message!


Yes I understood and all I saw was an anime trying at all costs to sell the image of intelligent without being in; fact; intelligent. Darling in the FRANXX is nothing but a patchwork of Evangelion, Gurren Lagann and Eureka Seven; a lot of flaps that do not mix and that do not work well.


We have two concepts, two cores, which do not connect at all and that is why 45% of all the mess that this anime is; the first core being what is presented to us until the ep. 20 and the second core, which practically arises out of nothing, in ep. 21 ... the two concepts have absolutely nothing to connect them in a way that works, throughout all plot twists (which is where all the narrative bets, another fatal error) and it is not at all natural to think that the signs have always been there, right under our noses; with every plot twist that is presented to us, we only feel more underestimated as a viewer and as a thinking human! At no time do we get the feeling that things are happening in an ergonomic way, develops from kicks... only for the anime to sell itself as smart.


Darling in the FRANXX tries so hard to be more of a classic; like Eureka Seven, Gurren Lagann and Evangelion, tries so much that forgets what makes a classic indeed a classic:

Coherence.


And at no time do we see coherence throughout any narrative development; either by the design of the mechas, by the -ride- jokes, by the construction of the world, and by the -absurd- ignorance of the children who know what romanticism but do not know what a kiss is (and I will not even get into the instinctive question that any animal possesses to know where to put his pipi). 


Coherence is where DiTF fails terribly, it's your second mistake and, then we have the error of narrative pacing. Everything in the narrative is out of place, to begin with that the explanation of world is in the middle of the anime when it should be in the first episodes, that is, Darling in the FRANXX also suffers from: out-pacing.


Perhaps, throughout all the suffering to finalize this anime, something has caught my attention; the characters, even in the midst of all the drama (in which the viewer is not taken care of at any moment) was what led me to continue watching. The characters do not have any development (except for Kokoro and Mitsuro, doubtfully), but it led me to think that:


1. If DiFT did not sell itself seriously;

2. If the two concepts were worked out properly;

3. And, especially, if the narrative were performed at the right time;


Maybe we would have an acceptable anime.


But that's not the case: Darling in the FRANXX is absurdly bad.

Let me start off with a small disclaimer: I am but a humble plebeian who simply enjoys good storytelling and compelling characters. If you are expecting to find a tear-down of why this show is bad, go somewhere else. I will try to be fair, but know that this review comes from a place of praise rather than cutting criticism. Also, I watched this show after it had been fully released, so this review is for all those who did not have to wait weekly for an episode to come out (or however it was released).
This anime surprised me in a lot of ways. Iwas surprised to find that after watching about 10 episodes, I checked what the fans thought of this show, and was astounded to find that this anime only has a dismal 7.5/10. I came expecting something along the lines of Pacific Rim, and was surprised to find something much more than that. I wasn't expecting how they would develop the story, and there were many times when I thought they were just going to end it, but oh wait, there's 12 more episodes (which was good in my mind)! I was surprised to find myself actually crying at merely thinking about the show afterwards; and so on and so forth.


I got far more from this show than the shallow sex-mech show people portrayed it to be. I was glad I gave it the usual 3-episode treatment and didn't let other's criticism taint my view of the show, as this show had me asking all the right questions about the world and characters to keep me vested beyond those first three episodes, which I would say is crucial to any well-made story. The way the world was portrayed was organic, without the usual full-episode information-dump other shows employ, but rather through character dialogue and observation. While the overall feel I got at first was like Pacific-Rim mashed with Elfen Lied and Evangelian (I actually have never seen the latter, so forgive my ignorance) with a touch of Anthem (by Ayn Rand), it brought something new to the table for me in how it portrayed all those differing ideas.


I mentioned that people portrayed it as a sex-mech show earlier, and this is something I can maybe see where they get the impression from, but where I think people may have mistook this show. At first they really hinge on piloting the Franxx (and yes it seems a bit sexual initially), but later on there is in fact a large portion that is just the characters learning to live together as a community and has nothing to do with piloting the Franxx. Even the supposed sexual nature that we see at the beginning is explained in much more detail later, and really shows that all along you were supposing the wrong things.


They did well showing how each character would react to their given situation, and to me the characters didn't feel cookie-cutter at all. What you thought one character would do is subverted by instead what another character did which affected how the original character reacted to a situation, giving you this sense of how developed each character is. Or at least, that the writers took time and effort to show how each character would react, making the characters feel more dimensional than the usual cliched, flat, dead-panned responses. You have some of the initial tropes, like the audacious go-getter, the sheepish girl, the bookworm, the smart and intellectual guy and girl, and then the crazy new girl (among others); but they expand and develop these characters to be so much more than the initial tropes you thought they were.


This review is starting to get a bit long, so let me end it with a few more short points:

1. The love story in this was spectacular, and while some might argue that it was a bit cliche, isn't that what any love story is? Romance is about two people falling in love. And if that's cliche, then life might as well be cliche because people are born, live, then die. How utterly monotonous (says the sarcastic me).

2. Towards the end there were a few twists, which may have felt slightly (I hate to use the word again) cliche, but one which I could embrace because it was so interesting I wanted to see what happened next.

3. I've never written a review for an anime, but this made me want to, especially seeing how much crap people were throwing at it. Which for me speaks volumes.


All-in-all, this is now ranked among my top favorite anime (of which there are few, and only one of which affected me to the same degree this one has). The love story made me wish that some day I could have so deep a love for someone else as what the characters had, it had me laughing and crying, it moved me, and it told a heartfelt story about what it means to live a full life. To me, that's more than I could have ever expected from this story, and I hope I can soak in more stories that move me in the same way this one has.

Darling in the Franxx began with so much potential, much of which can be attributed to the team's past works, with Gurren Lagann being one of my favorite anime of all time. Darling in the Franxx begins with decent marks, with a straightforward "get in the mecha, shinji"-esque plotline. 
However my enjoyment and overall excitement for the show dramatically increased with the introduction of side characters, the largest of these being the introduction of the 'Nines' and the 'Klaxosaur Princess'. However, I was slowly let down in this regard because none of these characters actually recieved any attention whatsoever and were moreso just thrown intothe story as filler, with the only development of them coming from seemingly nowhere with nothing to support their dramatic change in character. 


My other gripe with this show is the plotline in general. As of episode 10 I was lead to believe that this was going to be a story about overcoming the dystopian society and 'breaking out' per-say. However, past episode 10 we never see the inner workings of the society or the mastermind's motivations for creating this system. Instead we receive the most irritatingly slow 8 or so episodes all centered around the love interests of Squad 13. This is what kills the show for me. Instead of integrating the extremely interesting dynamics of the world, or developing new characters such as the ones listed above, we receive a "love interest of the week" style show where a different character falls in love every single fucking episode. And yes, I understand that the main motif of this series is "what it means to be human", HOWEVER, it is completely unnecessary to have as many love stories as this show has in order to achieve that motif. My main problem with this is the love that develops between 2 certain characters, as unlike the others, they haven't been together since childhood, and haven't even been piloting together for more than a month(?). It comes seemingly out of nowhere yet this is the side character love interest that the story chooses to develop the most! The 8 episodes in the middle of this series are just completely useless in developing the story of the show and by elaborating on the love interests within squad 13, the show neglects the cool and interesting plots and characters that are elsewhere.


In conclusion, just rewatch Gurren Lagann as it does everything this show does but without all the bullshit.

I feel like Darling in the FranXX was badly read, and although I don't feel particularly strong to it (the score is very barely an 8), what the anime actually ended up doing is lost inside what was expected it should do, and also in how derivative it was in regard to what it was perceived as its influences.
(This review contains spoilers)
There's a quote from Kurt Vonnegut in his Paris Review interview that explains what is so frustrating about Darling in the FranXX's story: "If a lover in a story wins his true love, that’s the end of the tale, even if World War IIIis about to begin, and the sky is black with flying saucers." Vonnegut is saying this pejoratively, about how a love story consumes is context and renders the surroundings void. It's how he explains why he doesn't writes love stories. Darling in the FranXX is a love story.


But to tell this story, it was created a whole universe with an extensive background of cosmic proportions, of ancient advanced races in a million years old war: but this war doesn't concern us. Humans are somewhat neutral (morally, at least) victims of this war, appearing through evolution in the wrong planet, and then used by the big evil alien devouring space conscience as pawns in this conflict. This use happens through cloning, control and overall emotional abuse of teenagers, created and trained to sacrifice themselves to their monarch or god but actually alien overlord. A big part of the cruelty of APE's control of their lives is the negation of their emotions, and the wiping of their memories.


So, this actually impacts the themes of the anime in several ways:


1) Structurally, the episodes of the anime are dedicated to the relationship of the characters in a greater proportion than the cosmic arc that appears at the end. Most of this cosmic backstory is actually told via two intensively expositive episodes. I don't feel like this is neither rushed nor bad, but actually an expression of the show's intent (being a love story).


2) The anime touches on several classic anime philosophic tropes: what it means to be human (or monster), what are the characters place inside those societies, and so on. Those are answered with a single word: Love. Is this a good answer? Probably not. But it is an answer.


3) Love is actually what differentiates humanity in this conflict between VIRM and the klaxosaurus. For one, love is the answer to VIRM's proposition of incorporation, and a life of tranquility in a spacial consciousness -- instead of losing oneself in a big, amorphous consciousness, we connect with each other through love, achieving an oneness that is actually stronger, and more fulfilling, than VIRM's alternative. This is the one-winged bird metaphor that opens and guides the series. Second, klaxosaurus answer to VIRM's invasion was to abdicate of individuality and transform its population into either magma-energy, or giant war machines in wait for the next phase of the war. What is significant between those two approaches is that they're both about power. What is different in humanity's approach is that it very much isn't.


4) This leads us to the end stretch: Zero Two goes to fight the VIRM out of love for Hiro. It's not particularly to save the world, not particularly out of a sense of duty. Hiro joins her out of love, so that she doesn't suffers alone, out of the promise to love her and be with her. There is no need to defeat the VIRM for their fight isn't about power, but about protecting humanity's life choice. And this they do. The end is about rebuilding life: life beginning out of love (i.e. babies), negating the exploration of other species (stopping the use of magma-energy). Meta-textually, is about retreating from a sci-fi future to a simple, old and organic one, leaving the big robots to gather moss and devoting themselves to agriculture and so forth. Is also, and very paramount, about living without the fear of death (which is what APE used to enslave humanity to begin with), which is also a very important point of japanese philosophy.


5) And Zero Two and Hiro's love is so strong that, even as they sacrifice everything to save the world (and to be together), their souls spend centuries voyaging through the universe, until they find each other again, now as a part of a humanity that their love has saved. But now Zero Two can love in peace, without the pain of feeling like a monster, and they both without having to be war heroes. They are allowed to achieve what the anime posits as the climax of humanity's way of life: Love.


I don't think those points answer if this is a good anime (I think it is, somewhat), but I wrote mostly as a way to defend that, for an anime that is so defined by its influences, I feel like its originality is actually being lost in the static created by those influences, and it deserves, at least, a fair shot.

A bit of advice before watching this show? Stop after the first 6 episodes. Seriously, because it is all down hill from there. Well, if you wanna watch the beach episode then stop after 7 eps. If the show had only been 6 episodes then this review would have been like a 9 maybe even a 10. I loved it...... and then it kept going, and going, and filler episodes kept happening until Trigger realized, "Oh shit we only have 5 episodes left and we haven't done anything." Lets see what happened. 
**This will contain spoilers**
The story is complicated in that you can separate itinto 5 arcs. 

The first arc is the 6 episode introduction. The world is lost and whats left of humanity gets around in giant mobile cities. The energy these cities run off of, attracts monsters. So the cities are defended by robots, piloted by young-ish teens. For the teens, this is the highest honor and if you cannot pilot, then you are a waste of space. This is the main characters problem until he meets a weird horned girl, known as the partner killer. The story over the first 6 episodes, is that "can this MC survive the 3 ride minimum with this girl." The rest of the cast tries to stop him and keep him alive. Over the arc we learn about a love quadrangle. The first arc is almost perfectly paced and stuffed with emotion and story. 

Then we hit the second arc, and it is a big boot on the breaks as we are given 6 episodes of essentially filler. Gone is the focus of robot battle, in is the struggle of teen angst, antics and relationships. Some of these episode are fun, but keep in mind that watching this as it came out meant over a month of no serious development. It was a world full of questions and we were getting almost nothing. 

The third arc is 2 episodes and they are GREAT. We learn about the past that the main character and the horned girl share and that they were linked by destiny.... or an STD or something.

Then we get the third arc and guess what? its 7 MORE FILLER EPISODES. Including 2 "special non-episodes." Sure over this time, there are some things revealed and relationships deepened. However, its not the main characters, its two side characters that get the spotlight for most of this arc. 

Then finally we get into the rushed, horribly paced/explained 5 ep. ending arc. Here the story takes a sharp right, as Trigger tries to turn the show around with a Gurren Lagann style space war between two galactic powers.... OUT OF NOWHERE. The only reason we see this coming, is that all Trigger's shit expands into space. But this time to shake things up, they do not show you the battle. ALL OF THE MAIN CHARACTERS STAY ON EARTH AND START LITERALLY FARMING INSTEAD OF IN SPACE WITH ROBOTS FIGHTING. Then in the last episode they go "OH SHIT, WE'RE THE MAIN CHARACTERS AND WE NEED TO GO TO SPACE." The last ep is the worst paced episode by a mile. 


The art is one of the saving graces of the show. It is consistently good to great. Both the animation and artwork holds up until around the end when it just turns into a bunch of laser shooting. One thing I noticed is that for an important scenes the camera switches to a widescreen shot. This is an interesting choice. However, after a while you become conditioned to not pay as hard attention unless the widescreen is on. 


The sound is not very noticeable outside of fight scene music. The mood music and sound effects are not really emphasized. 


The main characters seemed very tropey to me. This is where other peoples enjoyment may differ from mine. However, I did not hate these characters at first and wanted to know more. Then as the show goes on, you learn that they only have one or two defining characteristics and cannot hold up the amount of filler demanded by them. I do not think characters like miku or zorome ever get any development. They are pretty much the same for 24 episodes. There is also a group of "rival elites" who never get any development. The show wants them to be important but does nothing to help build them. There is also never a fight between the MC's and these elites. Then on the last episode the elites decide to help the MC's and sacrifice themselves for the greater good. Even though their face turn was done mostly off screen. It is like trigger forgot to write these characters.


Overall, I feel that this show would have been better if it were 12 episodes, they cut out the rival elite characters and slowly told us the story instead of doing long stretches of NOTHING, followed by literal plot dump episodes. I am very disappointed in Darling in the Franxx and so far it is 0-2 for trigger flagship shows. I did not like Kill La Kill for similar reasons, but I can at least see why people liked that show. I do not know how anyone can defend this show. Thank goodness for Space Patrol Luluco and Little Witch or I would avoid Trigger like the plague in the future.

Normally I don't write reviews unless I feel something needs to be said. This is one of those times. 
The first few episodes of the series had me thinking this was just another anime light porn setup disguised as a mecha series. However the longer the series ran the more it was obvious there was much more to it.
Story: Consistently written. Confusing at first until you have all of the information, then it makes perfect sense. I know a lot of people think this is some propaganda by the government of Nippon/Japan, but it hit home for me as a U.S. citizen. Blind devotion, unquestioningsacrifices. There's a lot to unpack but it's worth the effort.


Art: The fight scenes are very well done. The characters and the machines are given equal attention. Nothing feels like an afterthought.


Sound: The music fit the anime really well. There were no standout songs but it was still pleasant. 


Characters: The main characters felt real. They are children tasked with adult roles and behave accordingly. You feel empathy even for the side characters, which isn't common.


Enjoyment: This is one of those series I'm sure I'll come back to for a rewatch. 


Overall: Again, there are some reviews that seem to follow a disturbing trend of bashing shows because they saw one thing one one website that told them it was bad. This is not the case. "Darling in the Franxx" is a show that should be watched and judged on its own merit and not the whim of others.

Darling in the FranXX is quite the wild story that kept me questioning what would happen next at the end of each episode. [Minor Spoilers]
STORY 7/10:
The first part of the story is a frenzy of emotions with Hiro who is about to fail as a parasite himself discovering the woman who will forever change his life, Zero Two. It seems pretty cliched and lighthearted from that point going forward- they learn more about each other, their relationship grows, etc. But Hiro and Zero Two's relationship isn't what makes it special. Seriously, when the whole "destiny" factor is taken out it's really all just platonic truelove.


The story thrives with the other characters of Squad 13 learning about these emotions that Hiro is experiencing with Zero Two, finding remnants of the past in the Garden and learning new things, and seeing destroyed structures of the past while on their trip to the beach. The way the Squad reacts to all this is what makes them who they are and fills up the first part of the anime. I'll say more on them in the Character sect.


The second part of the story is where Trigger adds their usual side of craziness to the mix. This part gets a lot of hate for being all over the place and pretty hectic. Honestly though, they just swapped from an anime that focused on the romance complex with a side of Mecha to one that dealt less with the romance and more with the Sci-Fi part of the series. All the questions that arose in the first part of the show couldn't have been answered then, but, with what had happened to start the second part, DiF set itself up to answer everything that we had been wondering from the very beginning. The relationships between the characters remained generally unchanged throughout this part, so they focused on the origins of the world and what Squad 13 would do to change it from that point on. Even if it was quite sudden and nothing extraordinary, it was decent and ended the anime on a note where some questions (mainly one about VIRM) remained but still would satisfy.


CHARACTERS 7/10:

The characters all grew in their own way and were generally ideal protagonists from the start, from when Hiro named them to when they lived in as unique a place as the Garden. They are decent as characters themselves but their individual growth is where they truly shine. I'll just quickly analyze Squad 13 and Zero Two:


Hiro: a generic protagonist with really nothing outstanding about him besides his relations with Zero Two. He's more of a plot device that spreads his new experiences about what makes someone human to the rest of the squad (once again via his relationship with Zero Two).


Ichigo: regardless of popular belief, she isn't bad at all. In a matter of fact she grew the most out of the squad, learning about jealousy, trying to deal with it in every possible way until she just can't anymore, and coming to an acceptance with her unrequited feelings for Hiro. She becomes the best leader that she can for the squad and learns how to deal with the insane decisions that Hiro makes in the end.


Mitsuru: he literally changed so much it kinda scares me. I had assumed that he'd be a quiet spiteful character but in turn he actually became very passionate after coming to terms with Hiro and finally realizing his reason to live. Even after what happens to them he's able to find the same light in his life and takes from Zero Two and Hiro's relationship to make the most of his and show his true caring self.


Goro: his persistence and unwavering feelings for Ichigo, almost like Hiro's for Zero Two (just not as extreme), defines his personality. A brave co-leader, someone who can keep the squad in shape and keep himself in shape too. He's a very rational person who uses this to help others with their feeling and decisions.


Zorome: a bit of comic relief but also pretty naive at first, always believing in the authorities decisions, no matter how irrational they were. He learns about independence and adapts to the many situations in which he can't rely on Papa by instead relying on his own friends.


Kokoro: a lot of her changes include spoilers, so in general what's significant about her is what she learns about the past world and her curiosity to recreate what she reads about, practically to the point where she'll do whatever she can to understand what she doesn't through experience.


Futoshi: a bit like Ichigo's complex with Hiro, and just like her he grows from it and becomes filled with a passion to motivate what he can't attain for the happiness of the person he holds unrequited feelings for, Kokoro.


Miku: she's a bit like Zorome with her behavior but less reluctant to leave her life in the hands of others compared to him. She was more compelled to live for herself like the others were when that time comes. Outside of that she didn't really stand out much which made her a bit of a redundant character, especially when she's a protagonist.


Ikuno: she was pretty apathetic in the first part of the anime, but as things progressed she too realized what she wanted to live for (like Mitsuru), and although she herself knew that her feelings, which she had been hiding, weren't going to get any response, she comes to terms with it and uses it as her driving force to help the squad out from that point onward.


Zero Two: her internal conflicts between whether she could live for Hiro or wouldn't be able to because of their species barrier was fun to see unravel as she broke down over and over and Hiro would fix her up yet again. This alone isn't good enough to make her best girl, but with the constant strife that she goes through and is put through throughout the series shows not only her toleration but also her reluctance to give up on the treasure that she had found in Squad 13. Along with her gradual but eventual acceptance of the rest of the squad (namely Ichigo) she finds that there is a bit more tat she can live for than just Hiro. 


With a main cast this big, some of the characters were dwelled on either poorly or quite well. Together they are just your average rebellious group, but apart they each have their own complexes that intertwine and help move the story along. That, as I said, is where these characters truly shine.


ART 9/10:

Studios Trigger with A-1 Pictures. Honestly, what more could you want, the art of the characters and explosions easily had Trigger styled elements to them, but the scenery and landscapes were all handled by A-1. Great job overall.


SOUND 6/10: Outside of the amazing OP and the EDs that were as good, the OSTs to DiF are okay, but nothing all too special. Nothing much besides the OPs and EDs, though some of the emotional scene music is pretty good.


ENJOYMENT 8/10: Although many people would rather watch normal romances or different Mecha anime, DiF is truly enjoyable. The first part gets you hooked with the flying emotions and the dynamic in which they are placed to create a squad that can tackle the second part with barely any setbacks. They leave you with questions after every episode (except the last of course) and answer them in their own way at the best of times.


OVERALL 8/10: Darling in the FranXX gets very discredited as a whole because of its haywire ending to the series, or the last few episodes at least. This however should never distract people that this series brought back some elements of anime that we haven't seen much of in the past couple of years. Whether you'd want to compare this with Evangelion and see what Evangelion did better than DiF is up to you, but this anime standing alone is really good and something that we probably won't be seeing in a while. It wasn't wildly innovative but it did try new things that can hook anyone to the series. It's generally easy to pickup and hard to put down even if you dislike it because it keeps you wanting more until the very end. If anything it'll leave you with a feeling disappointment compared to just plain disliking it. It's a very good series by Trigger and A-1 Pictures.

For a moment, take Neon Genesis Evangelion and Guilty crown then try to put them together. This anime took what those two anime series failed at and made it work. This is an anime that I just thought I'd give a try and wow, did I love it. It was a greatride through it all and I'd say I was mostly satisfied. Since this is spoiler free, I won't go into details, but there are some thing I would've preferred to have gone differently. But overall, this is one of the best anime of the summer.


Story 8/10- The general concept of the story is good and certainly interesting. However, it isn't necessarily something new. These post-apocalyptic types of anime are popping up all of the time now. However, the story between Hiro and Zero Two is very cool and amongst the other children too. I'd say as far as the events going on with the characters, is the best part of the series.


Art 9/10- All around very good art. The colors and animation are very pleasing are almost never lacking.


Sound 9/10- The soundtrack for this series is certainly nothing short of great. I can't complain about any of it, but it isn't perfect.

Overall 9/10- I definitely reccomend this series, if any of what I have said sounds like this series might be for you. Well, chances are it definitely is. It's always nice to have a great series going on that is so short.

Like most of Trigger’s previous anime, Darling in the FranXX is one grand presentation in service of a greater idea or message. It’s been thought through just as much as you’d expect from the studio, so you can pick it apart for days on end and still be finding new visual details, dialogues, or cuts of animation that carry some level of meaning or significance that’s trying to get your attention. Something that I think we can all agree on is that all Trigger shows, whether you think they’re good or bad, are trying to say something specific and, more importantly in this case, they’retrying to deliver that message to a very certain someone. Please know that Darling in the FranXX is no exception; if it’s not trying to talk to you then it may seem lackluster, but if it just so happens that YOU ARE the target audience, then you will almost certainly fall in love with it.


Darling in the FranXX is trying to talk to romantics. It’s appeasing to your sense of emotional connection, and it’s equipped with a fully stocked cast of characters that are all meant to give you some form of catharsis. The setting of Darling in the FranXX is a post apocalyptic one, so the teenage characters (who are conveniently in male/female pairings) are living in military situations that are extremely mentally taxing. The melodrama that ensues from their relationships and lives as soldiers is the typical set up for emotional conflicts and their following payoffs. Every character conceit is planned, and their execution is predetermined from the start, so you’ll never feel like side characters were betrayed by the writers. Everyone gets their own arc and message to tell you. The thematic takeaway for each was also very intentional, and they take good time to portray these themes when appropriate so you can both listen to what the show is saying, and learn from it. 


Darling in the FranXX is also trying to talk to theorists. It’s appeasing to your sense of wonder and intrigue. The codified language of the show really has you asking questions from the get go, and it answers these questions periodically such that you have enough time to come up with your own conclusions, just in time for it to surprise you with a twist, or reward you with a confirmation. It’s a war story set in Earth’s future that has the teenage characters fighting a war against Klaxosaurs, which are basically robotic dinosaurs, on behalf of a shadowy figure they call “Papa”. It’s all extremely interesting in nature, and your questions will drive your investment in the story: Why are the soldiers called “Parasites”? Why are they even fighting? Who is Papa? What are Klaxosaurs? How did the world even get like this? All these questions and more will have you excited the whole time, and the plot will do nothing but throw you down the rabbit hole of mystery and discovery. 


Darling in the FranXX is also trying to talk to connoisseurs of animation. It’s production value is through the roof, and every episode looks better than all the low effort garbage you’re watching elsewhere. It’s no Kyoto Animation, but it pretty much has everyone else squarely beat. Trigger’s past anime such as Kill la Kill, Space Patrol Luluco, or Inferno Cop are infamous for being rather comedic and inventive with their animation; you can’t say that they’re technically well animated, but they work with what they have creatively enough to pass and be consistently entertaining. Darling in the FranXX IS actually well animated: It’s a mecha show, and all the main character pairs have their own uniquely designed robots that are all consistently hand-drawn throughout the entire show. The environments are creative, dense, and straight up cool so you’ll always be looking at art instead of a boring slate. The character animation is expressive, poppy, and generally telling of their respective personalities such that you can tell every frame had some level of care and attention to detail that most other studios simply cannot compete with. 


Darling in the FranXX is, lastly and most importantly trying to talk to optimists. For a show that takes place in a hopeless, desolate wasteland of a world, you’d expect every scene to have a very drab feeling to it, but that’s very much not the case. In fact, Darling in the FranXX boasts not one, but two fulfilling love stories that have both emotional and even sexual payoff. Both are warm and lovely to watch, but the main couple, the two main characters Hiro and Zero Two, has both more screen time and more meaning to it. If you think about it, this world that Hiro, Zero Two, and the rest of the cast live in is truly horrific, and even despite the fact that people are dying constantly around them, even despite having no volition over their own military circumstances, these kids have found a reason to keep fighting and, in each other, found warmth, relationships, and true happiness. Hiro and Zero Two even found true love, something that might inspire the others around them. In light of these hopeful circumstances, you can find yourself questioning your own life choices and circumstances: Are you really living your life to it’s fullest? Are you really being honest to the people you care about? If these two can continue fighting and loving one another in such a broken world, then what excuse do you have in a world that's still (mostly) held together? Whatever the answers to those questions are, the show still has you thinking about them, and that’s what matters. I’m still a virgin; I’ve never kissed anyone; I’ve never gone out with anyone; I’ve never even held anyone’s hand. I’m pretty certain I know where life is going for me. Though, one day, if fate is on my side, I’m sure I’ll find my “Darling”, and it’s stories like Darling in the FranXX that remind me of this.


So that’s it, yeah? 

All positives; no negatives? 

Perfect ten out of ten masterpiece, right?

What are you? Stupid?

That doesn’t say Trigger.

That says Trigger AND A-1 Pictures, so strap the fuck in boy and girls, because I’ve got something important to tell you.


As it happens, the script of this anime wasn’t written, in part, by Trigger staff at all. In fact, it was chiefly written and composed by A-1 Pictures. Thus, and I’m really sorry to tell you this, the script is an absolute fecal tornado; It’s a toilet typhoon; It’s a shit squall; It’s a turd tempest; It’s a dung downpour; It’s a manure monsoon; It’s an excrement earthquake. I seriously don’t have any other methods within my lexicon to express the reality of this situation to you. The script is simply BAD. 


Alright, so you got a two cour show, that’s about eight hours of screen time. Long time. Now, what do you expect? If your answer is cohesion, flow, organization, or anything at all related to good pacing and satisfying execution then you couldn’t be any farther from the result. Remember those ingenious plot concepts, character conceits, world building, and thematic messages I wouldn’t shut up about? Well, Darling in the FranXX takes every possible pleasure in squandering all their potential in the most unnecessarily disappointing ways you could imagine with incompetent genre juggling, non-sequitur character actions and reactions, filler style episodic stories that rush character arcs, endless info dump storytelling, full flashback episodes to explain concurrent events, laughable amounts of plot-armor, fully retconned events (that were supposed to be important), contradictory narration, and a good ‘ole switcheroo that flips the whole show on it’s head in the last four episodes to rush an unearned climax out of nowhere. Plot points and characters alike become jokes to you; it’s a complete and total mess. 


What I said before is all true: Darling in the FranXX is trying to talk to romantics looking for meaningful relationships and emotional catharsis, theorists looking for a thought provoking plot and world, connoisseurs of animation who are looking for a well animated show of epic proportions with densely drawn artwork, and optimists looking for joy, happiness, and hope. I am all off the above, and this show did successfully reach me on those levels, but it’s objectively broken script and messy execution made it impossible for me to appreciate most of it’s efforts. In the end, what could’ve, and very well should’ve been the Neon Genesis Evangelion of this generation, turned out to be the Guilty Crown of this generation. 


It genuinely saddens me to say this, but I do not recommend you watch Darling in the FranXX. Especially if you’re a Trigger fan like me; it will do nothing but disappoint you.


Thank you for reading.

Alright, so enough of these 6 episode reviews suddenly becoming a trusted source of information from people who think they're hired by the local news agency and got an A in one test of English class to warrant their paragraphs about every little god damn thing. I'm just gonna be as simplistic as possible but hey that's pretty much me, except I write reviews once a series is over not when it's just fucking begun.
So lets get this straight. This series is pretty much over at the time of writing this and I personally believe it's slowly descended into an overall below average anime. Ithink it started out with real potential and well worthy of being one of those weekly series which you know is gonna be interesting or like one of the "biggies" if you're like me and basically watch everything a season has to offer.




So pretty much it's this futuristic Earth where shit has gone down because a minority of elitists with optimistic but strange characteristics have took over as rulers of the earth voluntarily and their main changes are discovering that the Earth's core can be harvested as a great alternative source of free energy, but doing so has awakened far into this future some creatures that have been attacking the colonies of humanity thought to be attracted by this earth magma that's being resourced. To defend the colonies, the Franxx pilots were introduced which are kids brought up with complete obedience to the rulers who have called themselves 'Papa.' The story follows them gaining their own conscience and realising what they're fighting for, if anything and basic philosophy of their own purposes in life, including relationships and all that shiz.


That's basically it, of course you can trivialise and explain how much more to it there is but I couldn't care less because it would get to spoilers. I am not very experienced with Mecha genres but I really don't think there is any need to. This opening concept is pretty interesting and in the first couple or maybe half of the series it's great at building this world and the kind of environment in which these kids live, however I'd argue it's main flaw later on is abandoning this great concept and focusing too much on the character relationships which turn into a confusing shit show with it turning into some kind of waifu argument over anything else.


The majority of battle scenes etc are well animated. Not to the point of One Punch Man or the Gatari series or whatever, but sure it's good. Some others however feel quite confusing to watch, as during battles you may not understand what's going on with all the lasers flying everywhere and expecting that just because you hear a typical "HEEEEEEEEEERRRRRRRRRRRRRRRAGH!" from a character as they're preparing an attack in their mech, something must be going on because you sure as hell cant visually see what's happening. Sound is also pretty passable, with the voice acting being nothing to complain about and soundtracks being fitting enough but not necessarily fitting the same impact as the context on screen.


My main problem with this series is how it turns from an interesting hook on future reality to some kind of teen rom com, which although I don't shy away from usually, there's an extent where I am willing to join the ride and I did stay till the end but just to see how far it would go. I like the little relations between the characters but it just seems way to quick of a jump and ignoring the premise of what happened to this world and why things are why they are, being replaced with all these mind boggling plot lines that add pandemonium and not really being explained, leaving someone like me to go "Wat just happened."


Basically, it's a decent series and I guess you can watch it if the synopsis and theme is interesting enough but I'm just saying none of that synopsis explains anything about face mechs or random 'magic' that just happens.


I rate an 7.5. 8 for me seems to generous seeing as I never give anything a 10 and rarely a 9. I apologise for giving as little information as possible in this so called review, but most of all I think this series requires some kind of warning to it's initial hook. It's really not concerning as you get what you see, but it really does strange, confusing and hard to find any real conclusion that you actually understand.

EDIT: tacked on some post ep-24 thoughts at the end
the short version of this review is: watch eureka seven
the long version of this review (feat. some spoilers) is:
i'll start off with the good things about the series because there's a lot less to talk about there. the art, animation, overall production quality is very good. this makes sense because of the studios behind the project so as far as the visuals go franxx more than makes the cut.
unfortunately, however, good art =/= good story (but i'm getting ahead of myself). i do think that characterization is done fairly well: i'd say there's not a single(major) character in the cast that doesn't have some type development and i do like some of the writing choices they made (specifically the way they handled futoshi -- who pushed aside his own feelings because he wanted kokoro and mitsuru to be happy as well as ichigo wrt ikuno's feelings). 


the show's overall writing, while a mess, also had some good plot points (zero two and hiro's scenes were especially moving near the middle of the season but that may be my bias towards those tropes talking). 


but that's about all i have to say about the show that's positive. the rest is... not so good. for one thing the way the major plot regarding the "true adversary" of the show is silly. it's entirely left field and while i'm willing to give the writers some credit if a season two is planned (which would make the twist less Out There if still not introduced poorly) it was ultimately clumsy and far too abrupt with absolutely no build-up. i sat there in awe when the twist was revealed and not in a good way. they pretty much damn the pacing for the remaining episodes to be awkward.


additionally the world building itself is rather weak.

while franxx introduced an interesting take on the concept of immortality, the timeline and actual lore behind the technological advancements nullify any sort of philosophical impact the topic could've had. it just doesn't make a whole lot of sense and is, again, handled clumsily like pretty much every other plot element of this show.


really, it just seems to lack direction. 

nothing is explained in a satisfactory way and at times one may even question if the writers even know what they're doing. 


it's just. sloppy.

the high notes are high, of course, but not nearly enough to salvage this mess of a show. if the writing was a little more focused, definitely, this show would be much, much stronger but as it stands, even as beautifully as it portrays certain tropes, you're much better off watching something else that does an entirely better job of handling the topics that franxx wishes to portray.

**ANIME FINISHED*
My goodness, this anime has truly proven itself to be one of the biggest disappointments of the year: and we're barely into the summer season. 
In the months that it has taken for me to digest this series; I have gone through numerous versions of this review, and now, as it seems to be turning to it's final page; I feel confident enough to release it to the public.
- - - 
STORY (2): Originally I chose to ignore immediate faults of this anime; at the time I was blinded by the excitement that was Mecha. Unfortunately for me, the more I began to watchthis anime: the harder it became to ignore the seemingly brighter flaws. 


"Darling in the FranXX" is an episodic mess: and I believe that owes to the fact that the director, Atsushi Nishigori, has previously only produced the anime iDOLM@ASTER and various  unconnected episodes of other minor anime's. Although each episode in "Darling in the FranXX" is well done, it fails to deliver a comprehensive and enjoyable overarching plot.


- - -


ART & SOUND (6): The artistry and acoustics in "Darling in the FranXX" is perhaps the only redeemable quality of the anime. Although they aren't terrific in comparison to other pieces of work released by Studio Trigger and A-1 Pictures; they do paint a clear picture of what this anime was attempting to be.


The soundtrack for the entire anime is fairly well done, that much I can commend the producers for: however, that is where my compliments end. The animation itself is none too special and the designs of characters and the main antagonists are lackluster and without creativity. The designs and animation may look good at a first glance; but that is all they are, and for that very reason, I can't give this category above a six.


It simply doesn't tick enough boxes.


- - -


CHARACTERS (3): The caricature in this anime is so appalling that I can't begin to fathom the writing process that it underwent. From the unlikable characters, seemingly improvised backstory, and poor resolution: this anime has enough symptoms to be diagnosed with a terminal illness. 


However, that is not to say that all the characters in this anime have been distasteful: it's just, when the writers of "Darling in the FranXX" produce quality, they seem to carelessly destroy what they've produced without much thought. For example; one of the main characters, Zero-Two, is originally portrayed as a rebellious and downright uncontrollable fiend: that's quite the necessity when the remaining 90% of your cast are practically docile sheep. Nonetheless, the writers chose to tune down her personality in order to compromise with plot and in doing so turned a once enjoyable character into a dull machine.


- - -


ENJOYMENT (5): If you ignore all the major issues that I have listed above: this anime is decently enjoyable. The flashy battle scenes and cutesy romance is enough to keep most viewers entertained, however, without it, "Darling in the FranXX" would be left sitting sorely in the dirt.


- - -


OVERALL (4): This anime is filled with enough regret to fill an Olympic swimming pool. There is no doubt in my mind that "Darling in the FranXX" originally had the bones and plot premise to produce an anime that would blow any competitor out of the water. Unfortunately, due to studio error, poor writing, and poor production: this anime is very out of contention for that title.


Overall, it's decently enjoyable and will be able to keep most viewers entertained. However, if you expect "Darling in the FranXX" to rock your world with outstanding quality, you will be very disappointed. If you're craving a Mecha; "Darling in the FranXX" will do the trick just fine, but in my humbled opinion, there are so many better choices out there.


- - -


Once MAL has returned to normal service, I welcome anyone to PM me with criticism or compliments: I hope to begin to produce better quality reviews in the near future. Thank!

Okay, before I write this review, I want everyone to know that a lot of these reviews that are given out with such low scores are either elitists who don't enjoy a hyped anime actually being decent or trolls who dedicate their lives to make sure that every popular anime gets a low review from them, take their reviews with a grain of salt. 
*NON SPOILER FREE REVIEW*
That being said, I think this anime is at a very middle ground in terms of it's overall quality. It's a two cour anime series made by the two anime studios; Trigger, whose works consisted of Kiznaiver, Killla Kill, and the more recent LWA, and A-1 Pictures, who has had a more so controversial track record, but are nonetheless good in their own rights as well. 


My general review goes as this:

Story: 8 (As of episode 13)

Art: 9

Sound: 8

Characters: 9

Enjoyment: 9

Overall: 9


Story: 

Let's get this out of the way first. I believe that Darling in the FranXX story is not the best in terms it's genre, being cliche at some points as well, but it overall has a pretty captivating narrative. The story is very reminiscent of Nier:A and Persona 5's story (A mix in between of sorts) where it throws some philosophical questions on existentialism and what it's like to question your surroundings instead of continuously following orders, which episode 13 dwells deep into. It also has an obvious moral compass, showing that adults in this anime are evil while the kids who are held captive and done experiments on to protect the said adults are the good people. It's a good mix of both games in terms of story. The first cour of this anime focuses more on the world building and characterization of specific characters; and while boring and sometimes deemed unnecessary for some portions of the anime, it all comes together for a perfect closure, and that closure being episode 13. I don't want to dwell too deep into why I believe episode 13 is a masterpiece in terms of a standalone episode, you have to experience it for yourself, but what I can say is that while the first cour wasn't suited for everyone, episode 13 gives the right blend of everything (characterization, ambitions, ect.) that makes it so that even if you hated the previous 12 episodes, you can't seem to hate episode 13. Before I would've given the story a 5/10, but episode 13 just easily bumped it up to an 8/10 by itself. 


Art:

The art I don't really have to go too deep into. It's beautiful, that's all I can say. If there is one thing A-1 pictures can consistently do right, it's make beautiful character designs and have consistent art throughout their series. The animation doesn't feel choppy, and side characters are still drawn to detail, even if they aren't a big part of the scene. Just seeing that made me happy as the animators wanted to go all out on this project, and it shows. 


Sound: 

The sound is also something that is consistently done well. I have no qualms on saying that even if the shows story or characters are complete crap, the Art and Sound could still easily make this anime a 5/10 alone. A lot of the ost is played at the right time in the right scene to give more of an emotional output, and that alone makes the sound worthwhile. The voiceacting in this anime is also top notch, I can not fathom how good episode 13 proves this point to be, you have to watch it to experience it, but the VAs are dedicated and I can't wait to see them in action for the second cour. 


Character: 

If you prioritize your 1st cour of a 2 cour anime series on world building and characterization, you better damn be sure that the product turns out good. Fortunately for Trigger and A-1 studios, it paid off in the end. Characters are controversial towards many individuals who review anime. Sometimes a character doesn't bode well with the person watching the anime, so they tend to score it less than people who resonated more with a character. For me, I thought all of the characterization that they have done was magnificent. Each episode was more so focused on one specific individual, there was not a time where it was focused on just one pair for more than 2 episodes, that includes Hiro and Zero two. An example of this was in episode 10 where it focused on Zorome and Miku's relationship, or episode 11 where it focused on Kokoro and Mitsuru. Every character, be it main or side, has some development to them and because of that, you can feel their pain and their emotions more as you continue watching the episodes. What I like about Darling in the FranXX and their characters are that none of them feel one sided or stick to their cliches for too long. Each character has their own ambition and motivation for doing what they are doing, and not all of them are fixated onto one viewpoint. An example of a character I thought progressed very well was Zorome. Zorome had a fixed viewpoint on his infatuation with the adults. He would always want to receive praise from them, and do his very best so that he doesn't upset them, believing them to essentially be gods, but once episode 10 rolls around and he finally gets the praise he deserves, but then gets denied by one of them (handshake), he starts to change his perception and as a result, isn't fixated onto that viewpoint anymore. Each individual doesn't stay to what they believe in, they mimic us people IRL, we always change, and they always change as well once they start realizing more about the world around them. To say that the characters in this series aren't well flushed out or are one dimensional, you have to be crazy, because I think that the characters in this anime are the best. 


Enjoyment: 

This anime was not too bad in it's first cour, but once Episode 13 comes along, this anime just brought my enjoyment factor through the roofs. I believe that if you're able to bear through the slow build when it comes to the world and characters, then you'll have an amazing payoff, and will enjoy this series a lot. It's not meant for everyone, and that's understandable, but give it a chance before you brush if off, as you shouldn't judge a book by its cover.


Overall:

Overall, This anime is not suited for everyone, but it's nonetheless an amazing anime in terms of it's story, art, sound, and everything else. The people who are giving this anime such low reviews are doing it to suit their elitist tastes, and I don't think it deserves to be ridiculed this much. It def. deserves a rating higher than 8.03, and if the second cour is half as good as episode 13 was, I think this anime could easily be anime of the year hands down. Hope you enjoyed this review! :)

A ruined world full of mysteries in which the main characters begin to question and try their best to understand themselves, and in fact, the current status of humanity itself. Darling in the FranXX tries its best to focus on this theme, and is doing it quite well.
Story-8
The idea of a destroyed world in which the small remaining human population tries to survive is no new idea, as it has been used many times not only in the anime universe, but just about everywhere else. Because of the Klaxosaur attacks, much of the world has been destroyed, and these small remaining groups of humans utilizetheir new understandings of technology to fight back. Darling in the FranXX points out many times how this huge advancement of technology is a dystopia and is taking away the aspects of humanity, especially by characters like Zero Two, who sometimes states how the city of adults are "lifeless". Parts of life such as puberty are seen as negative and dangerous, and many important emotions such as love seem unknown. This enhances the already overused theme, making it much more interesting and thought provoking.\n
Art-9\n
Trigger studios and A-1 Pictures are well known for producing some of the best art in animation, such as Sword Art Online from A-1 and Kill la Kill from Trigger studios.  The overall art is amazing, with a western and cartoon character style. The visuals are very beautiful, and especially shines during the mecha fight scenes against the Klaxosaurs.\n
Sound-9\n
I don't have too much of an opinion on the soundtrack, but the OST sounds quite great. Some of the OST's have a similar style to that of Yuki Kajiura, where operas are used to enhance the current mood of the scene. The opening song is quite good, as well as some great ending songs.\n
Characters-8\n
A large character cast is hard to handle, as each character needs a proper amount of development. If a character is ignored and rarely used, then that character loses its purpose and becomes a dead-weight to the series. The story has to juggle back and forth with characters so that each character feels important and vital for the story while not reverting too much time from the actual main protagonist. Done correctly and you get a story with enjoyable and likable characters, but done poorly can result terribly, as most likely the character is only used as an excuse to force the story forward for a small moment. Darling in the FranXX does a decent job with its large character cast, as each character seems somewhat useful while still keeping a good amount of focus on Hiro and Zero Two. This is AMAZING, and I hope it makes the best of its potential in the episodes to come. 
It feels like the lovechild of all different sorts of anime, what with the staff behind it too. Almost in spite of that though, Darling in the FranXX is reining in on a narrative style slowly developing as its own, with things like the recurring use of cinematic black bars to highlight a scene or the particular way the characters are set up to interact and mature along the course of the story. Zero Two is the flagship character that seems to establish the new identity givenbirth here in the face of all these narrative influences and references. 


I think a large part of watching this show CRITICALLY, not to undermine its value as an independent work, is to understand where it's coming from and the things its referencing, whether it's in the show being a loving antithesis to Evangelion, or in its merging of the male sexuality in Gurren Lagann with the female sexuality in Kill La Kill to make a show that seems to speak about both, and on much appreciated softer levels throughout. A very clear facet of the show is how it fascinatingly becomes a closed critical history on its own side of anime, being a commentary on that history by introducing its personal take on it.


But not thinking about criticism for criticism's sake AS I FEEL MANY PEOPLE ARE UNNECESSARILY DOING, when you sit back to see what this anime has to offer and take it all in, there's no need for the comparisons. It stands up by itself as something unique and special, which you can feel as you watch it, especially coming off the first episode. I think it has one of my favorite first episodes ever.


I can't say too much on the ost for now. At this point, all I can really say is that I've not felt any gap in the good usage of ost so far. Strelizia's Awakening is awesome and it along with the OP and ED's contribute to the overall distinctness of the anime quite well. And on the opening. WHOA! At first subdued and alluring, but then with the perfect amount of smooth yet energetic vibrato accented by electronic sounds set to a familiar pop rock backbone (with great lyrics), it sets the tone to this show since the themes bouncing around here aren't groundbreakingly new, but the atmosphere breathed into them is something nuanced in a way that I'm loving!


Back to looking at it critically, the only thing I could wish for so far is more concrete plot development with each episode, as it doesn’t yet carry a goal rushing momentum from episode to episode. It seems to sacrifice that for character interactions to carry through in the future with some being more isolated “arcs” than others as well, which all by itself isn’t a bad thing since it’s a great decision to dedicate that time when given the ability to. However, it leaves some more “SO THIS IS WHERE THIS ANIME IS GOING!” to be desired, even when that looseness is brought to the fore as part of the anime’s appeal. Still, I don't dislike this direction of the story and characters since I think it does what it does right for what I seem to be understanding of its core intentions. 

Considering that, the most recent episode did well to advance the underlying plot of the story a little more-- if not momentarily-- in introducing background plot threads along with its character focus, which I hope can be built up more fully alongside the character development and interaction.


Also, some remarks on its fundamentals. The directing and dialogue are very good. Not every line has to contribute to a deeper understanding or story, but if you notice, they DO contribute to a richness in immersion and can be identified as tangents to a deeper character. Pay attention to the dialogue!! It's a lot more engaging than you'd take it for on first glance, especially with the expressive character animation. 

Speaking of which, anime is known for just sticking to a frame and changing the mouth. Darling in the FranXX doesn't do that much and is great at bringing in a variety of shots to a single conversation, which is part of what goes into the smaller things you have to realize in order to appreciate when watching it. It has solid directing when the moments call for it, which is what I was trying to get at in mentioning the black bars earlier, and THAT RIGHT THERE is what's setting it apart from the ground up.


All in all, it feels like everything’s been fun while working towards the show’s thematic purpose. Anyways, it's got me hooked, so with that, up to Episode 10 I give it a 10/10.
